dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moonlight. A magical forest of trees. Diamond shards of blue light on wrinkled, wormy roots. Over the mossy gorse steps -- A little TAILOR, with scissors, needles and thread hangin from his belt. A glass key round his neck. And a tall, grey hound beside him. He sees ahead -- A giant stone, where a crack opens up. The Tailor peers inside. And squeezes down inside a dark tunnel. Which leads out into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shimmering hall of phosphorescent light. The Tailor see a tall glass dome; and a shining glass coffin, on a velve pall, surrounded by moths and butterflies. The Tailor peers inside the glass dome, sees -- A miniature castle, with windows and battlements.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE GLASS COFFIN
dialogues.text: The Tailor peers in, to see: a sleeping PRINCESS, her breath ruffling her golden hair. In her hands: a box, lik a@ green ice egg.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: The Tailor -- takes his glass key, slips it into the lock (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ... And the little tailor thought to bend and kiss her perfect cheek, because he knew this was what he must do...' And kisses the Princess. She opens her eyes, full of wonder.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCESS
dialogues.text: You must be the one I have been waiting for. You must be the prince.

dialogues.speaker: TAILOR
dialogues.text: No, you are mistaken. I ama tailor. In search of work to keep me alive. The Princess laughs. And the sound of her laughter SHATTE the GLASS COFFIN into splinters. And on the box, CLOSE IN and --

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ... I am the resurrection and the life,' said Jesus. “He that believeth in me, though he were dead, yet shall he live...' SLOW FADE UP TO a silvery BLACK AND WHITE --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The box lies in the hands of a widow, MRS. ELLEN ASH, in front of a mausoleum. It's a dripping November day, sun l in the sky. Ellen lifts back her veil to kiss the box. Which she plac inside -- a wrought iron vault. Its doors close.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND
dialogues.text: Let the body and soul of Randolph Henry Ash lie in eternal peace, mourned by his sorrowing widow Ellen... PULL BACK to see Ellen and mourners, men in black hats an cloaks like silk-clad ravens round an Egyptian-style vaul tomb. Ellen focuses on the box behind a metal grille. HOL ON -- the box. As before our eyes, the box and tomb rapidly -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Age a hundred years. Roses wither and die. Moss, weeds, leaves, briars, tendrils of undergrowth push and coil ‘ro the grille.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: honored not only by those of the year of our Lord 1888, but by all of time... And as a wind blows leaves, FADE UP TO --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The spinning wheel of a bicycle. The spokes blur in a constant motion, giving an illusion of stillness. As -- Suddenly VIVID COLOR and SHRIEK of CAR HORNS -- A young man weaves perilously ‘round a worm of traffic. I anorak and cycle clips, ROLAND MICHELL, thirtyish, dodges down back streets, cutting through into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roland wheels his bicycle to sheds, removes his clips. Oblivious to his trousers splashed by mud. He unpacks his bicycle panniers. Heads through a side entrance into!--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roland walks down a long corridor, leading through to an ECHOING domed hall. He pauses by a party of TEACHER and school-kids in front of a statue of an eminent Victorian: Randolph Henry Ash.

dialogues.speaker: STATUE
dialogues.text: Roland stares fondly up at the stern features of Ash gazi lifelessly out over the kids' bored faces.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: Poet, philosopher, naturalist, statesman, Randolph Henry Ash was one of our most eminent literary heroes... (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ‘ whose famous love poems to his wife Ellen are among the most glorious jewels of our literary heritage. From the Victorian age, only Browning and Tennyson --! (to unruly kids) Pay attention, Kylie --! Who stare amusedly at Roland's nerdy appearance, cycling helmet still on. He slips unnoticed down a side stair-wel entering --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through a door marked, "Ash Institute: Director Professor James Blackadder." This is the "Ash Factory": <A basement of corridors, in institutional grot. Strip lighting, peeling paint-work. PAOLA, a fifty-something secretary with moth-like glasses glances up at Roland.

dialogues.speaker: PAOLA
dialogues.text: ‘Morning, Roland. Blackadder's in a panic. Mortimer Cropper has landed.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Oh, God. Did Blackadder finish my reference? I asked him weeks ago.

dialogues.speaker: PAOLA
dialogues.text: I reminded him. But you know what he's like when Cropper's in town.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I must talk to Blackadder. He knows since he gave that job to Fergus...

dialogues.speaker: PAOLA
dialogues.text: Accident? Notices his ruined trousers, on her way to the photocopie

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: (hadn't noticed before) Oh... my bicycle, I suppose. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roland puts down his panniers, squeezes past Paola into t pantry. He flicks on the kettle. Looks for his coffee mug

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Who's been using my mug? As he unscrews the coffee jar, waiting for the kettle to boil, he turns to see at the door, a grey-haired woman, staring at him.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: If you have a minute, Roland... This is Dr. BEATRICE NEST, doyenne of Ellen Ash studies a Keeper of the Ash Museum, an eccentric spinsterish schola

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Actually, Beatrice, I was about to get started on those Ash footnotes!--!

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: It's important. It's about Ellen... Ominous silence. Roland registers Beatrice's insistence. She disappears down the hall. Roland has to follow her in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A musty cavern of cardboard boxes and yellowing papers. Behind them, almost bricked in, sits Beatrice. Who flings letter over to Roland.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: I can't bear it. Another letter from that impossible woman, Leonora Stern. She wants a piece from me for some ghastly new journal about Ellen Ash's sexual relations --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: With... Ash?

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: With anyone. This woman's obsessed with sex. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: You protect Ellen from questionable suitors, Beatrice. I've always admired that.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: Ellen was a faithful wife. And I'm faithful to her. She needs protection. I'm the only one now who cares... NOISES in the corridor. Two academics poke their noses in One, his rival, a trendy young lecturer, FERGUS WOLF; the other, a bluff elderly Scottish professor, JAMES BLACKADD Roland's boss.

dialogues.speaker: FERGUS
dialogues.text: Hi, Roland. Still here?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Fergus.. (beat) Congratulations on your appointment... Downcast, Roland shrinks back in defeat. Blackadder blusters in.

dialogues.speaker: BLACKADDER
dialogues.text: Ah, Roland... I want you at the London Library. Come along, Cropper's in town for the auction... Blackadder whisks Roland out from the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk down the corridor with Fergus, Blackadder putti on his coat.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I feel sorry for poor Beatrice. Even the feminists hate her now for championing a dull wife --

dialogues.speaker: BLACKADDER
dialogues.text: (exasperated) Beatrice Nest and her bloody letters of Ellen Ash are completely irrelevant to modern scholarship. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BLACKADDER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She's wasted twenty-five years looking up every recipe for gooseberry jam and jaunt to Broadstairs. That's what I get for hiring a Ph.D from... (can barely say it) New Zealand.

dialogues.speaker: FERGUS
dialogues.text: The old witch. She's the best keeper of the Ash Museum you'll find

dialogues.speaker: BLACKADDER
dialogues.text: Yes. Like Ellen, Beatrice is best behind closed doors... Blackadder and Fergus swoop off. Roland watches them go, turns ‘round to see -- Beatrice scurry back into her room like a crab. Obviously overheard their comments. Roland sighs --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The spinning wheel. On his bicycle, with his panniers and clips, Roland swerves through noisy traffic, heading for

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An elegant London square. Roland cycles in as leaves blow from a tall tree towards a vast Victorian library, where people leave by stone steps, armfuls of books. As Roland parks his bike -- Some LEAVES float away, tumble towards a skylight on the library roof TAPPING like birds trying to enter, as --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roland enters the shabby hall. Bespectacled scholars shuffle around in a silent hum. Roland seems suddenly "at home." All around him, wasted lifetimes devoted to books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roland navigates like a mole accustomed to the dark throu amaze of metal shelves. Hidden stairs and tiny corridors like a Piranesi prison, books piled high: dark, dusty, infinite... Roland seems to know his way, even in the dark...

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Zig-zagging through a labyrinth of books, Roland emerges down in the basement. He knocks at a door marked "Rare Books 5." No reply, so he enters -- A musty room like a pharaoh's tomb, a high window casting light into a cell of vellum and leather. Roland puts file down.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: My name's Dr. Michell, Roland Michell. You have a copy of Donne's poetry for me. An 1858 edition. A pebble-glassed LIBRARIAN emerges, crooked as his totter piles of books. Slightly deaf, he takes his time.

dialogues.speaker: LIBRARIAN
dialogues.text: You ordered it through Professor Blackadder over at the Ash Institute?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Correct. I'm working on the Complete Works edition with him.

dialogues.speaker: LIBRARIAN
dialogues.text: I didn't know Ash was an admirer of Donne?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: He quoted one of Donne's poems on his deathbed. I'm checking references in the Nineteenth Century editions... just to be sure. The Librarian finds Roland's book, bound with tape. He wipes away black dust, hands it over. Roland sits down, cracks pages apart. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LIBRARIAN
dialogues.text: Doesn't look like it's been touched for a while. I'll check... Flicking through, Roland sees notes scrawled in the margi

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: It intrigues him.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Someone's scrawled notes all over the margins.

dialogues.speaker: LIBRARIAN
dialogues.text: Hm...? Well... it's never been called for, as far as I know... (checks file cards, as Roland reads) Odd... According to our records, this edition was bequeathed to us by Ash's widow, Ellen.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: You mean this copy belonged to Ash himself? Someone must have consulted it before now.

dialogues.speaker: LIBRARIAN
dialogues.text: Seems it was lost in our filing system... Intrigued, Roland goes back to cutting leaves. With great delicacy he cuts open a set of pages, suddenly two old letters fall to the floor. Roland bends down to pick them up --

dialogues.speaker: LIBRARIAN
dialogues.text: (rambling on) . Devil and Demonology, Dogs, Domestic Servants and... Donne...' (beat) You can lose anything in here. I found a set of false teeth once... Roland isn't listening. Dazzled by a thin shaft of sunlight, Roland starts to read. On yellowing PAPER, a sound of a PEN SCRATCHING. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: And Ash's voice -- deep, intimate -- OVER:

dialogues.speaker: ASH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ... Dear madam, Excuse this letter to a stranger. Yet since our pleasant and unexpected conversation at Crabb Robinson's party, I have thought of nothing else...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On hearing Ash's voice, Roland turns the letters over. Li a spell, the voice stops. Roland stares hard at the letters, then looks back at the Librarian. Concealing the letters from view. Warily, Roland turns the letters over again. As Roland reads the next passage, his expression changes to wonder.

dialogues.speaker: ASH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ... I feel, I know with a certainty that cannot be mistaken, that you and I must speak again...' He reads on, silently. Then turns the letters over again. He folds back the book to the front paper: A signature "Randolph Henry Ash." Roland pulls the letter up beside t signature --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Incredible...

dialogues.speaker: LETTER/SIGNATURE
dialogues.text: A match.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Like a great poker hand, Roland can't believe his luck. Suddenly alive, confused, palpitating, he looks ‘round.

dialogues.speaker: LIBRARIAN
dialogues.text: Hm...? Found anything interesting?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: deliberating. His heartbeat seems to pause. Time stops, his whole life converges in a single moment: Life or deat truth or lie, a simple "Yes" or "No":

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: No. Nothing really...  ll.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Guiltily, Roland slides the letters into his copy of Poems of R.H. Ash. And slips the book beneath his arm, as A loud KNOCKING sound CARRIES OVER from --

dialogues.speaker: AUCTIONEER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Sold once... sold twice...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hammer bangs on a gavel as an AUCTIONEER closes a deal. In a panelled room, a crowd of buyers sit waiting, some poised on phones, others with catalogues: Victorian Literary Memorabilia.

dialogues.speaker: AUCTIONEER
dialogues.text: Sold for a hundred and twenty-five thousand guineas... The tall, handsome buyer, acknowledges the Auctioneer: MORTIMER CROPPER, U.S. scholar, collector, master of the universe. Nearby, the elderly LORD ASH, and his wastrel son, HILDEBRAND.

dialogues.speaker: AUCTIONEER
dialogues.text: ... Letters and memorabilia of Randolph Henry Ash, including wedding rings belonging to the poet and his wife... to Professor Cropper. Behind him, Blackadder and Fergus Wolf exchange glances. Cropper acknowledges Blackadder, turns to Lord Ash.

dialogues.speaker: CROPPER
dialogues.text: We can rest easy, Lord Ash. The wedding rings are secured for the Ash Collection.

dialogues.speaker: LORD ASH
dialogues.text: You beat the Japanese again?

dialogues.speaker: CROPPER
dialogues.text: Of course, sir. We have very ample funds.

dialogues.speaker: LORD ASH
dialogues.text: (repeating vaguely) Very ample funds... Lord Ash smiles. Cropper comments to Hildebrand. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CROPPER
dialogues.text: Pleased to see your father so happy.

dialogues.speaker: HILDEBRAND
dialogues.text: Money always excites him.

dialogues.speaker: CROPPER
dialogues.text: Then we should go. No more buried treasure here. Your father's very frail.

dialogues.speaker: HILDEBRAND
dialogues.text: But not frail enough. Envy in his voice, as Cropper collects the rings. He whee Lord Ash's chair to the exit. Blackadder and Fergus gossi

dialogues.speaker: FERGUS
dialogues.text: You have to hand it to Cropper, repackaging Ash as a New Victorian. All moral rigor and family values. Pure opportunism! --

dialogues.speaker: BLACKADDER
dialogues.text: Now Newsweek picked it up, the old goat thinks he'll get a Pulitzer for his book. Hideous... (beat) But I wouldn't trust anyone, faced with Cropper's loot... Blackadder rushes up to Cropper.

dialogues.speaker: BLACKADDER
dialogues.text: Congratulations, Professor Cropper.

dialogues.speaker: CROPPER
dialogues.text: Ah, Professor... Dr. Wolf... Look at these rings. Wonderful things... He proudly holds up the rings before them. All look on.

dialogues.speaker: CROPPER
dialogues.text: I remember when my father would amuse himself by placing the treasures of his own collection in my sweaty paw... (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CROPPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (stroking his palm; sensuously) ‘ “Here, Morty, my boy,' he would say. “Here is history to hold in your hand.' Priceless...

dialogues.speaker: BLACKADDER
dialogues.text: Surely a strain even for your budget. Effortlessly superior, Cropper smiles condescendingly.

dialogues.speaker: CROPPER
dialogues.text: At the Cropper Foundation, we don't have a budget. Just a check book. Blackadder, Fergus watch him wheel Lord Ash out.

dialogues.speaker: WHEEL
dialogues.text: Roland rides up the lanes of rundown Stoke Newington. Outside a tall Victorian house, Roland stops, brings his bicycle up steps. Opens his doors, and enters --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Locking his bicycle in the hall, he picks up a pile of ma And wearily goes down the stairs into the basement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Portraits of Randolph Henry Ash stare down at a kitchen table. CATS gather, MIAOWING for food, as -- VAL, his long-time girl friend, sets down before Roland a plate of lamb and ratatouille. It's reheated, and like their relationship, tepid, and potentially poisonous.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Shall I get a bottle of wine?

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: You should've thought of that before. Roland dutifully picks at the meat. Then -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I made an amazing discovery today!--

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: It'll go cold.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I was in the London Library. I found Ash's own copy of Donne poems with all his notes in the margins. And I'm sure no one knew it was there --

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: I expect they didn't.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: ... If I tell Blackadder, I know he'll think it's important --

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: I expect he will. Roland sees the bad mood. Like a storm gathering strength

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to bore you, Val. It does look exciting. I can write it up. It'll make me a better job prospect

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: There are no jobs. And if there are, they go to Fergus Wolf -- Val gets up from the table. Roland dutifully prods the lamb.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: If you think what I do is so unimportant --

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: (lighting a cigarette) You do what turns you on. You have this thing about this dead man. Who had a thing about dead people. That's okay, but not everyone is very bothered about all that... (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (draws on cigarette) I see some things, from my menial vantage point in my lawyer's office. Last week, when Euan and I Roland starts to feed cats below the table.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Who...?

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: A lawyer. In my office... Oh, never mind. Val turns to him. At first slowly, calmly. Then louder...

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: I suppose I envy you, piecing together old Ash's world picture. Only where does that leave you, old mole? What's your world picture? And how are you ever going to afford to get us away from dripping cat- piss and being on top of one another?! Roland stares, stricken by Val's show of temper.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Something's upset you, hasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: Seems a reasonable deduction.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Three A.M. Outside a dilapidated Victorian house, a breez RUSTLES through a tree's LEAVES. MOVE IN THROUGH a WINDOW where Val lies in bed, alone. Outside the bedroom --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting on the lowered loo seat, Roland goes over the letters. He stares at the handwriting, hears Ash's voice. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ASH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: . Dear Madam, Excuse this letter to a stranger...' RUSTLED by WIND, with a strange, harmonic MUSIC, the lett hover delicately in his hands. Haunted by Roland's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ash escorts Ellen into the house, he carries on throug party, inside a conservatory of Oriental plants which conceal guests playing blind man's bluff. Ash sees a WOMA head turned away. ON that look --

dialogues.speaker: ASH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Since our pleasant and unexpected conversation at Crabb Robinson's party, I have thought of nothing else...' Ash is drawn towards the Woman -- FREEZE ON his expressio his features turn as if to stone, as -- END OF DREAM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crisp pages of a yellowing volume. Roland reads the journ of Crabb Robinson. An entry under 1858.

dialogues.speaker: CRABB ROBINSON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: June 18, 1858. My breakfast party went off very well indeed. I had with me: Mr. Bagehot, Mr. Ash, Mrs. Jameson... Professor Spear, Mrs. Lees, Miss La Motte and her friend Miss Glover, the last somewhat taciturn...' Roland locks up, scribbles a note: "Christabel La Motte." He dreamily sees --

dialogues.speaker: SQUARE
dialogues.text: In the conservatory, Ash, as before, walking towards a Woman, turned away from him (and us). (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The host, CRABB ROBINSON, a mustachioed aesthete, observe his guests.

dialogues.speaker: CRABB ROBINSON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Ash had never met Miss La Motte, who spoke more forcefully than I expected. She is surprisingly handsome when animated...' In BLACK AND WHITE we see as distant shadows -- Ash with Woman -- Christabel La Motte -- and behind her, another Woman -- BLANCHE GLOVER, an attractive, but less confiden artist.

dialogues.speaker: CRABB ROBINSON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: . We all discussed with Mrs. Lees her claim to have conversed with the spirit of Charlotte Bronte... Mr. Ash appealed to Miss La Motte on the question of visions and second sight; she declined to express an opinion, answering only with a Mona Lisa smile.' From Ash and Christabel's smile: Rapturous, intense... END _OF FLASHBACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Roland double-underlines the name "Christabel La Motte He takes his slip of paper to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing in a catalogue room, trousers still coiled by bicycle clips, Roland flicks through the cards in a gargantuan index. Under "L," he rummages until he finds t reference...

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: (mumbling) La... La... La... La Motte. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: "La Motte, Christabel 1825-1890. Poet, critic."

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: jots down a reference: 719.640. Moves down to related literature. Roland holds a card at arm's length. From behind, a voice:

dialogues.speaker: FERGUS, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: I didn't know you had an interest in Christabel La Motte... Roland turns, sees Fergus peering over his shoulder. Ferg reaches over to investigate the card. And laughs.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I don't. I never heard of her until now. (beat) Why did you laugh?

dialogues.speaker: FERGUS
dialogues.text: You're looking for an involuntary expert. There are two people in the world who know all about Christabel La Motte. One is Professor Leonora Stern from Tallahassee. The real expert is Doctor Maud Bailey at Lincoln. Cropper and I met them both in Paris. A conference on sexuality and textuality. (beat) A formidable pair... they have quite a thing together.

dialogues.speaker: . ROLAND
dialogues.text: A “thing'?

dialogues.speaker: FERGUS
dialogues.text: I don't think they like men.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Oh, dear.

dialogues.speaker: FERGUS
dialogues.text: Maud runs a resource center up there in Lincoln. Cropper's funding it. They've got Christabel's papers there. If you want anything, that's where to look. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I might. Thanks. What's she like?

dialogues.speaker: FERGUS
dialogues.text: Unreadable. The feminists are interested in her. Wrote a poem about a fairy who married a mortal for a soul --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I meant Dr. Bailey... Will she eat me up? Fergus considers briefly. A lot of undecodable feeling.

dialogues.speaker: FERGUS
dialogues.text: She thicks men's blood with cold. ON Roland's look, a mix of intrigue and worry --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The beautiful face of MAUD BAILEY: pale and cool, like a marble statue. Blonde hair up, Maud stands in a doorway o a modern campus block, as past campus fountains and lawns Roland walks toward her. As he closes in, he is drawn in her beauty. He recognizes it, yet cannot even admit it. She is middle-class, beautiful, confident: everything he dare not aspire to.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You must be Dr. Michell?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Yes... Roland... Maud offers him her long, cool hand. Roland puts down his briefcase, shakes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I hope you haven't wasted your journey, Dr. Michell. With neither a word nor a smile, Maud turns, walks into t faculty building. Roland takes a step, remembers his briefcase. Turns back to pick it up, and has to -- Catch up with Maud, now several steps ahead, opening a do to --  20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a new building of beige wood and tinted glass, Maud wa with Roland towards an elevator. Young, punky female students walk past, rings in their noses, holding hands. Roland sees no men.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: On the phone you said you found a connection between Randolph and Ash and one of my poets.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I found a draft of a letter in one of Ash's books. I thought it might be to Christabel La Motte.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: What sort of letter?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: A love letter, I think.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Hard to believe. Where's your evidence? Maud presses the button for the elevator. They wait.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: There was a breakfast party, June 18, 1858. At the home of Crabb Robinson. I believe they met one another there --

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You can never rely on Crabb Robinson. He was a notorious gossip, always inventing things... The ELEVATOR PINGS, opens doors. Maud and Roland step inside.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Of course, but he has some curious details...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the elevator, Roland and Maud are uncomfortably cl together, as they go down into the resource center's basement. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: el.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: : He says Ash and Christabel discussed each other's poems. And met the spiritualist Mrs. Lees. It sounded plausible to me. In 1861, Ash wrote Mummy Possest after a seance --

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: My Christabel was interested in spiritualism. But I don't think Ash would have appealed to her. His poem is full of hatred for women --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Then it's probably a wild goose chase. As you said. (beat) I hope you don't think I've made all this up. This relationship --

dialogues.speaker: _ MAUD
dialogues.text: You said connection.' Now it's a relationship?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Between two people. Two human beings. Isn't that normally called a relationship?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Depends. I think your theory is way off the mark. It sounds, frankly, a little bizarre. Maud turns away, heads off into the library. Roland follo her.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I need to cross-reference it with her journal. You did say Christabel kept a journal...

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: No. But we have a diary by a friend of Christabel. An artist, Blanche Glover...

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Crabb Robinson mentions Miss Glover. Who was she? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Maud picks up interest. The ELEVATOR PINGS, doors open. They walk out of the elevator, towards the library doors.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Blanche was Christabel's housemate - - and most certainly her lover. In front of the doors, Roland hangs back. Maud holds the door open.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Am I allowed in?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Naturally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a desk, Maud brings out a box of musty manuscripts. Sh picks a single volume, places it on the desk in front of Roland. A thick, green, leather-bound notebook.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Blanche's diary was among Christabel's papers when she died. Leonora is looking for a grant to have it edited. She's found a researcher from France who's interested. But we can't go through everything...

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Then I'll let you know what I find. Maud is about to go. She relents, giving in to her curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I checked my files before you arrived. Christabel only referred to Ash. In a letter she wrote to William Rosetti, towards the end of her life. (beat) It was... if anything... hostile. (beat) You have a couple of hours. Roland sits at a desk. Illuminated by a shaft of overhead light.  23.

dialogues.speaker: ON COVER
dialogues.text: A gilded dove, flying out from a keyhole. He opens the lavishly-illustrated book, with marbled endpapers. "A Journal of Our Home-Life In Our House in Richmond" By Blanche Glover Commenced on the day of our Setting up House May Ist, 1853." As Roland flicks to June 1858, her writing is decorated w pretty drawings, slowly merging into swirling, macabre images.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCHE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ... June 18, 1858. We went out to breakfast at Mr. Crabb Robinson's home. Present were Mr. Bagehot, Mrs. Lees, Mr. Ash the poet, though without Mrs. Ash, who was indisposed...' In his mind's eye -- Roland tries to penetrate a misty cl

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: (SILVER NITRATE BLACK & WHITE) - DAY (1858)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a garden conservatory, Ash moves towards a beautiful woman, back turned away from him. Behind her, as Ash draw closer is -- A woman, we now recognize as -- BLANCHE GLOVER.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCHE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: '... The Princess was much admired and rightly...' Ash is intercepted by HELLA LEES, a spiritualist. Who introduces the beautiful woman: CHRISTABEL LA MOTTE, a beguiling pre-Raphaelite brunette.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCHE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: '... She professed to like Mr. Ash's poem Ragnarok greatly. Which naturally flattered him...' Christabel returns Ash's smile. Modestly flirtatious, she is drawn into his orbit, staring deep into his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCHE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: '... This famous poet would have been much surprised to know my true opinion...' (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Blanche watches Ash walk with Christabel away from her.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCHE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: '... But I smiled and nodded as best I might, keeping my thoughts to myself. (beat) I desired to be at home.' Blanche holds in her hand a book, with an embossed gilded dove on its cover. Then --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Checking the clock, flips through yellowing pages of Blanche's journal, filled with portraits of Christabel.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCHE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: '... My Princess is much exercised about a long letter which arrived today, which she did not show me, but smiles over, and caught up and folded away...' Slowly her portraits change into macabre drawings of serpents and goblins. Roland returns to a page he's skimmed:

dialogues.speaker: BLANCHE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: '... Letters, letters letters...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the hallway, a pile of letters. Christabel picks them up, heads upstairs. Followed at a distance, by Blanche: Her face brooding and suspicious. As Christabel drops a letter -- Blanche picks it up, goes to the door, confronts her with it. Christabel runs upstairs, sobbing...

dialogues.speaker: BLANCHE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: '... Not for me. You need not hurry them away...'

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE HER ROOM
dialogues.text: Christabel hides letters in her sewing basket, folds them under handkerchieves. Outside, through the keyhole -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BLANCHE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: '... I am no sneak, no Governess. From that fate you rescued me, my Princess, as I shall rescue you from yours...' Blanche spies in.

dialogues.speaker: IN IRIS
dialogues.text: Her eye large, unblinking. Blanche moves back, stares out the window. The panes frame her face. A storm is beginning. By candlelight --

dialogues.speaker: BLANCHE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: '... Now we have a prowler...' Blanche sees tree shadows move across windows. RAIN and WIND HOWL outside. WINDOW FRAMES RATTLE, Blanche's anger mounts. As branches scrape over windows --

dialogues.speaker: BLANCHE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: '... I hear him out there. A wolf at the door...' Blanche watches as from outside something BANGS against a door. A low moan of CRACKING WOOD. A latch is BATTERED until ready to give. In a reflection, Blanche sees --

dialogues.speaker: BLANCHE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: '... This peeping Tom has put his eye to our walls. Now he peers shamelessly in...! A man's face -- Ash -- BOOM! A sudden GUST OF WIND. Windows and shutters are blown in -- rain pours through. silhouette -- a face like Ash. Then the WINDOW BURSTS ope Splinters of glass fly towards Blanche --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Dusk has turned to night. Beneath an isolated pool of overhead light, Roland looks up from the diary in darkness. Among the shelves, a shadow stirs. From the darkness --

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Did you find anything? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Maud steps into the light. Stunned, Roland closes the boo

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I think so. Alone together in the deserted library. Unexpectedly intimate, even erotic. Maud perches on a desk.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Do you know about this prowler Blanche was so worried about? The wolf at the door?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You think it may have been Ash? You saw her drawings. Blanche had a vivid imagination. On the desk, Roland and Maud flick through Blanche's maca drawings of labial flowers and serpents' tongues.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: And was jealous.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Possibly. If Christabel was her lover. Lovers do get jealous, don't they?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: What happened to Blanche?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: She drowned in the Thames, shortly after completing this book. Suicide. Christabel was distraught. It was all very sad. (beat) But it's getting late.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I need to find out what happened next.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Sorry, not tonight. The center's closed. Roland looks at Maud. Realizes now or never.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Then I'd better explain. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Roland takes out the two stolen letters from his pocket. tosses them on the table. Maud starts to read them.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I found these. They're in Ash's handwriting.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You're sure they're authentic?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I've checked. They're dated June 19, 1858.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: The day after Crabb Robinson's party.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Precisely. If I can find something definite, they could change our whole idea of Ash. (beat) And perhaps of Christabel. Maud's pulse quickens. She finishes, looks up, regaining her composure. Senses their importance.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I haven't shown them to anyone else. No one else knows they exist. I found them in a book in the London Library.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You stole them -- ?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I don't think they're mine, or anything. But they're not Cropper's or Blackadder's or Lord Ash's either. Don't you see? My Ash lived a quiet and exemplary married life. Now, suddenly... (beat) A love letter to an unknown woman. As Roland ties himself in knots, Maud is coolly accusator

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I suppose they might represent a considerable academic scoop. For you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Well, I wanted to be the one who does the work... (realizes her insult) ... Wait a minute -- it wasn't like that.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I'd never have the nerve to do that. Steal them...

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: It was an impulse. For the first time, I felt Ash was alive in those letters. It was incredible. That's why I need you to find out the truth about Ash and Christabel --

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You know Cropper funds the center. If he finds out --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: He won't. If you don't tell him.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I can't let you Xerox Blanche's diary. The spine won't stand it. Maybe you could copy it out. I need to think.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: You can't throw me out.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Can I book you a guest room?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I don't have any money.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I thought you were working for Blackadder.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Part-time. I also wash dishes in a restaurant. Maud mulls it over. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You'd better come back to my place. (beat) You can sleep on my sofa. Roland looks at the diary. The traces of the faded brown writing. As Maud's hand rests close by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside in the hall, Maud collects bedding, plays back an ANSWERING MACHINE MESSAGE from Cropper, as in her sitting room -- Photographers from Leonora, letters from the Cropper Foundation. An illustrated book has been left open for hi on her desk.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I found something for you. A first edition of Christabel's poem, The Fairy Melusina that Blanche illustrated...

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Can I read it?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yes. It's very beautiful. Critics still dismiss her poetry. But I always found it strange and powerful. There's one passage about a woman who'd give anything for a child, even a hedgehog, and duly gives birth to a monster... Roland looks at the macabre illustration. As Maud enters.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I think Blanche is sorry for the hedgehog.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Is she? (impressed by Roland's insight, Maud examines a picture) Yes, maybe you're right. Leonora thought it was related to Frankenstein, the product of Mary Shelley's horror of birth -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Thanks. I'll read it. Perhaps it'll help me sleep... (realizing his mistake) I didn't mean it like that. Maud throws him blankets. Glares at him.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: See you in the morning. There's a train every hour. Maud closes the door. Roland lies on the couch, listening to her in the next room. He settles down, picks up the bo of Christabel's poetry, starts to read. In shadowy darkne

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EMERGE as the IRIS OPENS OUT INTO a strange dreamlike pla of Christabel's secret imagination: a dark, sinister fairyland where owls cry, wolves howl. Through an enchant silver forest -- A distant KNIGHT in armor dismounts his weary blood- spattered horse. Over, Christabel whispers her poem:

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: '... A draggled knight came riding through the trees, Behind him fear, before him darkest night...' The knight hears a song from a hollow chamber: Inside a glass coffin, bound by silver chains and sapphire ropes, lies a fairy princess in white silk. She holds a goblet u to the Knight:

dialogues.speaker: KNIGHT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: '... What I shall become, I know not. But I crave a place of rest, A draught of water, for I choke on dust...' The Knight pulls back thorny briars, steps into the mossy hollow. He shatters the glass coffin, magically exploding into shimmering splinters. The Knight lets the liquid dro on his tongue, and -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sl.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: '... All one long look consumed his soul Into desire beyond the reach of hope, Beyond the touch of doubt or despair, So that he was one thing, and all he was --' As the Knight kisses her, her golden hair wraps itself around him -- silver chains and emerald ropes bind his limbs, cut through his armor -- from her mouth a serpent' tongue darts out -- Plucks his eyeballs from behind his chain mail visor. As the Knight lets out a painful roar, which freezes --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the book -- A horrific woodcut illustration: the fairy princess, as Roland catches his breath, waking up!-- Almost falls off Maud's couch. He checks a clock. Hears DROPS OF WATER. He gets up. On Maud's mantelpiece, Roland is drawn to -- An old photo of a young Edwardian lady. He looks closely the picture: a bride clutching a bouquet of flowers. On the back, an inscription: "M.B. On her wedding day." Intrigued, Roland hears the DRIPPING sound GROW LOUDER, a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the basement, Blanche's diary lies open. Shafts of moonlight on a deserted hall. A breeze blows, ruffling pages, past strange drawings of flying doves, as -- Past an aisle of desks, walks a shadowy figure, humming a childlike song. Along the floor, LEATHER SHOES SQUEAKING, soaking wet dress trailing behind her, sound of WATER DRIPPING... As this figure vanishes through double doors...  32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On her bed, Maud lies asleep on her pillow. A breeze blow Maud stirs, something enters the room...

dialogues.speaker: ON MAUD'S FACE
dialogues.text: Drops fall like tears. Above her, a pallid hand, delicate but withered. As Maud's eyes flicker -- At the end of her bed -- bathed in palest lilac light, Blanche's ghost stares at her, wet clothes DRIPPING PUDDL OF WATER. From her pockets -- Blanche removes stones sewn with thre into cloth. She snaps each thread, hurling stones up in t air over Maud, where -- They don't fall, but float in the air. Strange, silvery spiral shapes upon jet black surfaces --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside his room, Roland is distracted by strange sounds: The SNAPPING of THREADS, a SOFT HUMMING, then...

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No... no... no...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still half-asleep, Maud tosses her head. Until Blanche stretches out her hand, strokes her face. Desirous, tende filled with grief, Blanche leans over Maud -- INTERCUT -- Roland on the other side of the door -- as --

dialogues.speaker: BLANCHE
dialogues.text: My dear princess... Blanche's bedraggled tresses spill over Maud's face. Tenderly she lowers her lips in a kiss. But Maud -- awake -- a shriek -- the ghost vanishes, and -- Roland rushes in. Maud sits up, sobbing.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: What was it -- ?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I saw her... Suddenly, Maud looks up at him -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: You... Maud rushes into the other room, Roland follows --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud by the mantelpiece, next to the framed photo. Roland enters, puts his hand on her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I shouldn't have let you stay.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Maud, please --

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Go back to London. I don't want you here -- Maud picks up the framed photo, hurls it to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Please -- Roland gives her a final look: no chance but to accept.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: If that's what you want. Maud exits, shuts the door behind her. Roland kneels down to pick up the mess. Looks at the photograph: initials,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next day. Roland waits on the platform for his train. Mau waves briefly, hurries away. The train pulls in, stops, passengers board.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (over loudspeaker) The train at platform two is the London Inter-City, now ready for departure... Roland looks back, sees Maud getting into her car. A WHISTLE BLOWS. A moment of decision before the doors lock Roland -- Unlocks the door. Gets out --  34.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In time to see Maud driving away in her car. Roland hails cab, gets in. Sets off, following her --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud drives out of town into hills. Her car twists 'round country lanes, drawing Roland onwards. A dark sky glowers as --

dialogues.speaker: IN HER CAR
dialogues.text: Maud sits staring ahead. Almost trance-like. She drives t a place she obviously knows well. Roland follows her up t A remote village amid sweeping hills. At its edge, a churchyard. Roland loses Maud's car. But as he nears the church, Roland --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sees her car parked nearby. Roland stops his taxi.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Not much 'round here. Want me to wait? Roland checks his pockets. No money.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: No, er... (an embarrassed silence) I've done something silly. I don't have any cash -- The Driver looks at him. Then at his wrist watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (FEW MOMENTS LATER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Driver zooms off -- Roland's watch now strapped to hi wrist. As Roland sets off to search for Maud. He wanders round the old Norman churchyard. Over in the distance, stands Maud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fierce wind blows as Roland hikes up towards her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Out on a hill, over a deep, narrow valley, a graveyard. Maud hears him coming, swivels round as he stands over he

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I asked you to leave me alone. How did you find me?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Sorry. I followed you. I had so many questions... (beat) That girl in the photograph. 'M.B.' Who was she?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: May Bailey. Christabel's niece.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Why did you have her picture?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Sophie La Motte was Christabel's sister. She had a daughter called Maia. Everyone called her May. (beat) She was my great-great-grandmother.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: So that's why you're so interested in Christabel. The family connection.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: No. Christabel was so unhappy. I felt she was cursed. I always avoided her. But her poetry always drew me back. This is where Christabel died. Roland looks at the tombstone. In white stone, a female saint curves round a humble tomb: Christabel La Motte 182 1890.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: She died alone?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Christabel never married. She had no children. She spent her last years living with Sophie and her husband over at Seal Court. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Where is that? Nearby?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Not far. You can see it over the hill. A gale blows fiercer. Above, BRANCHES RUSTLE and CREAK. Roland picks up an old bouquet of rusting wire and dead chrysanthemums.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Can we visit?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I'm afraid not. It's not open to the public. I've never even been inside. Leonora tried. But she didn't get on with the owners. (beat) The wind is getting up. You should go now. I'll drive you to the station. This time I'll make sure you get on a train. As wind and rain blow across the saintly figure. Roland looks back up a hill. Silhouetted on the skyline, Roland sees glints of silver -- a person in a wheelchair, in difficulty.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Look. Up there... To Maud's annoyance, Roland heads off up the hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the hilltop, a wind blows as Roland rushes up. Maud follows behind. Stuck in mud, a branch has fallen in fron of a lady in a wheelchair: silk scarves, hat and boots: LADY JOAN.

dialogues.speaker: LADY JOAN
dialogues.text: I seem to be stuck. Bogged down. Foolhardy, my husband says. Most humiliating. Can you see the offending object -- ?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: (shifting the branch, slipping) There. It's out of the way... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Lady Joan lets off the brakes. Maud arrives up the hill.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Just as well we were up here. Are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: LADY JOAN
dialogues.text: I feel a bit shaky. My dog is meant to stay with me. Never does. Useless great lump. Useless... If you'd accompany me to the foot of the track, my husband will get me --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I don't know round here. Which way?

dialogues.speaker: LADY JOAN
dialogues.text: Down there. I live at Seal Court. My name's Bailey... Joan Bailey. I hope you don't mind. It's not too far... Maud looks at Roland, who suppresses an exclamation.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: We'll take you there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dusk. Rain. Roland and Maud push Lady Joan up a weed- infested driveway. A tall tower dominates a huge, crumbli Gothic ruin, covered in roses and vines. Escaping the storm, they enter --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A grand decaying hall. Stained glass windows, Pugin-style carvings, rotting velvet tapestries and RAIN DRIPPING NOISILY into buckets on stone floors.

dialogues.speaker: LADY JOAN
dialogues.text: Better come into the servants' hall. The only wing we use now. My husband should be there... Past a tiger rug on a wide floor, Roland, Maud and Lady J pass through a temple of taxidermy: surrounded by ancient stuffed animals: bear, lion... wildebeest. Sadly moth- eaten, dilapidated. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: On wooden panelling, a crest of arms: a crossed shield, held by unicorn and centaur. Now faded and abandoned, obviously broke...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roland and Maud sit in a kitchen of faded grandeur: piles of newspapers, pots of jam, old shoes, dog food, broken toasters... Her husband, SIR GEORGE, sits with The Sporting Life, watching TV horse-racing. While Lady Joan serves tea from china service, preserving an air of decorum.

dialogues.speaker: LADY JOAN
dialogues.text: I suppose we must be related, Miss Bailey. But the Lincolnshire Baileys never got on with the Norfolk Baileys. Family feud. (beat) Tea, Mr. Michell? You say you're a writer...

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Not quite. A research assistant. I'm working on a scholarly edition: The complete works of Ash, the Victorian poet -- Roland clears a space on the table. Sir George shouts up from TV.

dialogues.speaker: SIR GEORGE
dialogues.text: Old Tommy Bailey named a horse after him. Can't think why... Did him at school once...

dialogues.speaker: LADY JOAN
dialogues.text: We had a sort of poet in this house...

dialogues.speaker: SIR GEORGE
dialogues.text: The little lady poet. Terrible stuff about fairies...

dialogues.speaker: LADY JOAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Michell and Miss Bailey might like poetry --

dialogues.speaker: SIR GEORGE
dialogues.text: They can't like Christabel La Motte (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I do. We were visiting her grave. Sir George puts down his paper, glares at Maud.

dialogues.speaker: SIR GEORGE
dialogues.text: Who was that frightful nosy American female ranting about the state of the grave? You're not in league with her -- ? Maud kicks Roland beneath the table. Smiles at Sir George

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: No... I remember Christabel described the Seal Court garden in winter, as she walked there with her dog... Maud goes to the window, looks out onto an overgrown gard with a chipped stone pond at the center.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ghost of a hound walks across the landscape, then vanis

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: ... 'the sheltered bench and the silvery fish in the little pool... even under the ice, I could see them suspended. ' (beat) I've been studying her life.

dialogues.speaker: SIR GEORGE
dialogues.text: Not much of a life. She shut herself away in the East Wing tower.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: That's what she must have seen.

dialogues.speaker: LADY JOAN
dialogues.text: The east wing's never been used. I came here as a bride in 1929. No one's touched her room since then. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Maud looks through the window, a Gothic tower in rain and wind.

dialogues.speaker: LADY JOAN
dialogues.text: We must find the scones. I'm afraid we don't have too many luxuries here. But one has to make an exception -- (to Sir George) After tea, I think you should show these young people Christabel's room. That is, if they want to see. Roland looks at Maud, whose eyes betray her excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside, a storm. Up a towering spiral staircase Sir Geor leads with an old lantern. Maud and Roland follow with th Labrador, up CREAKING BOARDS; night sky visible through g in ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: SIR GEORGE
dialogues.text: No electricity in this wing. Closed since the First War... Roland stumbles, puts his foot through a rotten board.

dialogues.speaker: SIR GEORGE
dialogues.text: Careful... Don't want to lose you.. Maud and Roland look up the winding stair: a panelled doo with a latch. Sir George tries pushing it, then pulls it open. A wind rushes through, as --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By lantern-light, Roland and Maud see a panelled room wit box-bed, a mahogany desk carved with goblins, a rocking horse, heavy trunks and bureau drawers. In a wall beside the bay-window -- A gaping hole. A pigeon flutters out --

dialogues.speaker: SIR GEORGE
dialogues.text: Damn -- Sending the lantern's light across a mirror entwined with gilded roses. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: In its reflection, Maud and Roland see a row of -- starin tiny white faces propped against an embroidered cushion.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: The dolls -- On the bed: three dolls with china faces: gold hair, blac hair, and a white nightcap. All stare with blue glassy eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Christabel wrote poems about her dolls. Here's one... Maud picks up the cushion: embroidered with verses and daisy chains. Meanwhile, as Sir George inspects rain dama

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I suppose any papers were cleared from her desk. May we look? The wind blows out his lantern. The room plunges into darkness.

dialogues.speaker: SIR GEORGE
dialogues.text: -- Not now. Too windy. The boards are all rotten. Best wait until morning.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Morning...?!

dialogues.speaker: SIR GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'm sure Lady Jean will want you to stay --

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: But that's --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: -- very kind of her. Maud, still holding the cushion, glares at Roland.

dialogues.speaker: SIR GEORGE
dialogues.text: Good. Joanie loves having someone to talk to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside, a storm. Ice on the windows. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Steam from the kettle, as Lady Joan boils up for the hot water bottles.

dialogues.speaker: LADY JOAN
dialogues.text: I think we should get the bed made up, get some hot water bottles in it now. Don't you think, Dr. Bailey? Sir George scurries across with another antique hot water bottle:

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You're sure both of us can stay. This isn't an imposition --

dialogues.speaker: LADY JOAN
dialogues.text: Nonsense --

dialogues.speaker: SIR GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'll go up and see to the bed. I'll need help with the sheets --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I'll help.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: No. I'll go... Sir George and Maud head upstairs. Lady Joan fills the kettle. She has taken to Roland, addresses him affectionately.

dialogues.speaker: LADY JOAN
dialogues.text: I hope you haven't had a tiff, or something.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Tiff?

dialogues.speaker: LADY JOAN
dialogues.text: You and your young woman. Girl friend. Whatever.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Oh no. That is, no tiff, and she isn't -- my girl friend. I hardly know her. I've got a girl friend!--

dialogues.speaker: LADY JOAN
dialogues.text: (not listening) She's a beautiful girl, Dr. Bailey. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LADY JOAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Stand-offish or shy, maybe both. What my mother called a chilly mortal. (beat; holds up a hot water bottle) I hope you aren't frozen in that great draughty room...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wind, rain. A pristine, magical setting. Trees fantastically hung with ice, a pond glints in moonlight, water covering with ice. Frozen gold and silver fish swim beneath the surface, glowing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the old main bedroom, Roland -- in old jumpers -- make up an armchair as a bed. Bitterly cold. As they talk, Mau gets undressed, behind a screen.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You didn't have to stay the night.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Lady Joan wanted us to. They think we're a couple. Besides, they'll let us look at Christabel's room tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I could have come back on my own.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: You're stuck with me now. You'd never have got in here without me.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: That doesn't mean I'm grateful. Turn around... Roland dutifully snuggles into the armchair, as Maud emer from behind the screen in her bedtime outfit: a sugar-pin winceyette nightdress over long johns, knitted mittens, Arran sweater.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Then I'll have to tell Sir George how you and Leonora are such good friends. I'm sure he'd be very interested... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You wouldn't do that...

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Of course I would. Leonora must have really offended him. As Maud gets into her bed, for added protection from the cold and Roland, she puts on a knitted balaclava. Only he eyes are visible, peeping out.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: (getting into bed) She only complained about the state of Christabel's grave. But she got Sir George all upset. It ended with him firing shots --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Attempted murder. That's handy for blackmail.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I've heard enough from you. I want to go to sleep. Maud rolls over, an embroidered cushion next to her head. Roland lies staring at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: You know, in the beginning, they were very romantic --

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Ash and Ellen. He took her to the south of France for their honeymoon

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Roland, this is no time for a lecture --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I always think of them as having a perfect marriage, no children, just lives devoted to poetry -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Just like Christabel --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: At least they had something in common.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Good night, Roland.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Good night. Maud grabs the cushion. Roland switches out the light. Darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In another far-away bedroom, smothered in blankets and paraffin stoves, lie Sir George and Lady Joan, fast aslee With the Labrador curled up between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roland awakes.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Maud...? Maud is not beside him. Nor is the cushion. The candle ha burnt down. He gets out of bed, lights another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out into corridors, Roland steps with his light. He walks down a long hallway, reaches the east wing, the door to the tower.

dialogues.speaker: UP SPIRAL STAIRCASE
dialogues.text: Roland walks up, up, up. He reaches the panelled door. He pauses, pulls the door open, enters to see --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By candlelight, WIND still HOWLS in. Roland sees -- the golden-haired doll. He picks it up. And -- as he stoops down, Roland looks up to see -- Maud. He gasps in shock -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Quiet -- !! They might hear us --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: -- What are you doing -- ? Maud points to the embroidered cushion: a poem, sewn in a childish design around a daisy chain.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I couldn't sleep. I think Dolly is hiding something. Look... (beat) '... Dolly keeps a Secret, Safer than a Friend. Dolly's Silent Sympathy Lasts without end. Friends may betray us, Dolly's lips are sealed. Could Dolly tell on us? Much she concealed...' (beat) Give me the knife. Roland hands her the knife, Maud unpicks a knotted ribbon As the ribbons unravel, the silk gown opens up, padding spills out, and --

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Something's inside... Among tufts of duck down -- a package. Wrapped in white linen with tape like a mummy. Maud unwraps it, and out fa

dialogues.speaker: TWO BUNDLES OF OPEN LETTERS
dialogues.text: Maud picks up one pile: in handwriting: "Randolph Henry Ash Esq., 29 Russell Square, London." Roland picks up the other, to "Miss Christabel La Motte, Bethany, Mount Arara Road, Richmond."

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Ash's handwriting. Look at the dates. He did send it. How did you know?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I didn't. (beat) This is Christabel's writing too. Read yours. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Roland picks out a letter, written in Ash's distinctive handwriting. He can hardly speak --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: (reading the letter) '... Dear Miss La Motte, Excuse this letter to a stranger. It was a great pleasure to talk to you at dear Crabbe's breakfast party. May I hope you too enjoyed our talk -- and may I have the pleasure of calling on you...?!' (to Maud) And the answer? Did she answer? Maud takes a letter, carefully unfolds it.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: (reading the letter) The next day. '... Dear Mr. Ash, I am a creature of my Pen, my Pen is the best of me, and I enclose a Poem, in earnest of my great goodwill towards you...'

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Go on. Please... Maud holds up the letter. About to read, then --

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: No. It wouldn't be right.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You should read Ash's letters. I'11 read Christabel's.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: But why?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Those are the poets that interest each of us --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: But they're writing to one another!-- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: That's not the point. How can I be expected to remember Christabel's words -- ?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: But if they're love letters, don't you want to hear what he wrote to her?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Roland, please. This is not the time for your theories -- Maud freezes him with a glance. They settle on the floor, both take their respective piles. And sit there, opening letters in silence. Roland opens his, reads a little -- then stares at Maud. Who produces from her pockets a penc and some index cards.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I have some cards. I need to record her observations. It's a system I use at the center --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: This is ridiculous --

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I have to be methodical. We can eross-refer later. Just because you're unprepared --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Unprepared -- ? It's the middle of the night. I want to get a sense of what happened to them, how they felt

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Roland, you're a scholar. There's no need to get carried away. Maud goes back to reading. Coldly hostile, she doesn't lo up. Roland picks up his letters, starts reading. Silence. Their senses are drawn into the words, until -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (from the letter) '... Dear Miss La Motte, You encourage me more by your permission to write again, than by your wish not to be seen. Perhaps you will tell me about your Fairy Melusina poem...' Roland stops reading. He looks across at Maud. Who frowns with concentration, making neat notes.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Sorry to interrupt... (as Maud looks up) Was Christabel still living in Richmond when she wrote The Fairy Melusina?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: With Blanche...? (as Maud nods) Hmmm...

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Why do you ask?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Ash seems to have written to Christabel about her poem. At some length...

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Yes. Quite interesting... Roland lets it drop. But Maud's curiosity is piqued.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: May I look?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: A quick glance. Maud peers over, sees the reference. Looks up.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: What did he say? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I don't know. I'm just in the middle...

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Of course. Maybe you could...

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Read it aloud?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Just the reference to her poem --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Of course. If you insist... As Roland starts to read aloud:

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: (RICHMOND) - DAY (1858)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The postman walking up to their door, carrying the letter clearly in view. He pops it through the letter box, !as!-

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: '... Perhaps you will tell me about your own Fairy Melusina poem...' From the front window, Christabel watches him go. She --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- runs 'round to the hall, to pick up the letter. She ru upstairs, unaware of Blanche emerging from downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: ASH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: '... By your writing may I come to know your most secret self, though my eyes never see your person. When I write, then I know... Your friend, Randolph Ash...! END OF FLASHBACK.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND AND MAUD
dialogues.text: caught in a spell, in each other's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: How did she reply? Maud goes for the next letter. Then pauses, electrified --

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I can't go on. My hands are trembling.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Let me find it for you. (fiddles among the letters) It's the next day. They were writing every day. Roland selects the right datemark, pulls out the faded letter, hands it to Maud.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Do you want to read it?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Just this one... Who trembles as she opens it up. She looks up at Roland, she reads --

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: '... My dear friend, how shall I answer? Your inspiration means so much to me. Yet I feel I cannot continue our correspondence. Blanche and I have made a pact, chosen a way of life. I cannot choose to break it...' Roland watches Maud reading, his eyes over her face in th candlelight. Sensing their deep immersion in this love story.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: A rainstorm. Up the hill, Christabel and Blanche walk, followed at a distance by FOOTSTEPS. Outside their house, Blanche pauses, turns suspiciously. She sees nobody. They enter their house -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: '... You will say you are no threat to that. I know the threat is there. Perhaps it would be better if we ceased to correspond...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WIND HOWLS. A storm blows. From inside, Blanche looks out from behind shutters. The night of "the Prowler"...

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: '... The world would not look well upon such letters between a woman and a married man -- even if that man were a great and wise poet. Your friend, Christabel La Motte...' Down the street, stands a man in black cloak and umbrella next to a hansom cab. Windswept, lashed by rain, reveal - Ash, eyes fixed upon the house. Through trees on the window: Blanche. CRASH -- !! The WINDOW SMASHES, SPLINTERS --

dialogues.speaker: ASH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: '... I cannot forgive myself. I have no designs on your freedom. I know too well the unhappiness a lack of freedom can bring. This must be your choice. And yet...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A postman arrives, puts the letter into the letterbox.

dialogues.speaker: ASH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: '... Our inspiration is so rare, so special, I cannot think it better if we ceased to correspond...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THROUGH the letterbox, the postman's letter falls to the floor. It lies on the hallway, like an evil omen. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ASH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: '... I shall send you the manuscript of my new poem, with the ink barely dry, inspired by the thought of you... Ever yours most truly...' Christabel picks up the letter, only to reveal -- Blanche upstairs behind her. She swoops down, snatches the letter takes out pages of handwritten poetry. Christabel tries t retrieve -- A struggle. Blanche throws off Christabel's hand, who recoils. Blanche takes the poem, holds it up in front of her --

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: '... I dare not write more. Your poem is lost. I cannot be sure any further letter of yours will reach me...' Christabel walks upstairs, enters her room, closes the do

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: '... And shall I give up? No, I will not. If it is possible for you to walk in Richmond Park at eleven, I shall be there...! Out of the window, Christabel sees Blanche leave the hous

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks back up at Christabel, like a princess in the tower. Blanche clutches the letters in her cloak, hurries away. END OF FLASHBACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud looks up at Roland, faces by lantern light, surround by letters. Roland opens up another, hands it to Maud, wh pauses. Gently touches his hand, listening to the WIND

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: They're here with us now. Aren't they... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Roland looks into her eyes. Maud picks up a letter, opens it. In Christabel's handwriting, the words seem terrifyingly real:

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: (reading) '... This is a moment of madness. You have summoned me out of my tower -- and out of my wits. I did not think you would come...!' The WIND HOWLS, and with a ROLL of THUNDER --

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: Black clouds. A LIGHTNING STORM ROLLS. Lost in a silver forest, his horse tethered nearby, Christabel turns towar Ash. His eyes on hers, her pale face trembling, she holds out her hand to him.

dialogues.speaker: ASH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: '... And then it was my madness. For in that moment, I could take your hand... or not. Do the deed, or turn back forever. I was able to choose either path...' Ash reaches out, takes her hand, gloved. Puts it to his cheek.

dialogues.speaker: ASH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: '... And now only the one.' The moment of contact is too much. Christabel watches as Ash takes her glove, slowly unpeels it. Lets it lie limpl then -- Kisses her hand. A moment of perfect stillness. And in that moment, for the first time, we hear Christabel's voi

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL
dialogues.text: What are we to do? Ash and Christabel stare into one another's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ASH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: '... There is a fire within us which must burn...  55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By candlelight inside his study, Ash sits with his books, composing a letter to Christabel. In the b.g. --

dialogues.speaker: ASH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: '... I had a plan to go away to Yorkshire. There are reservations for two. I beseech you to accompany me. (beat) I shall wait at noon. St. Agnes's Church.' Ellen hovers like a ghost, peering out of the window. She looks out to raindrops on the windowpane. A servant remov Ash's bag, Ash kisses Ellen upon the cheek. And heads downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A driver waits, luggage and gear on a carriage. Ash gives letter for Christabel to a messenger. Who races off. The horses set off, Ash in the back. A CLOCK CHIMES. One, two three...

dialogues.speaker: ASH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: '... I write in haste. I fear your answer -- I know not whether to depart or no...' Besides Ash's carriage, another black carriage pulls up w a white crest. Then as Blanche steps out --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the back of the knave, Ash kneels in prayer. He hears the CLOCK STRIKE TWELVE. Ash turns, sees an outside door open slowly. Daylight comes into darkness. The candles flutter as --

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Did she go with him...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawn. Maud and Roland lie together, surrounded by the letters.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: There's one left. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You read it... Roland picks up a final letter. From Christabel's pile. H reads it in silence, intrigued by its contents.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: It's from Christabel. She asks Ash to return all her letters --

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Is there any more? There must be... Frustrated, Maud rummages among the letters. Suddenly, a door opens, Maud and Roland looks up to see -- Sir George staring at them.

dialogues.speaker: SIR GEORGE
dialogues.text: What in hell's name -- ? On the floor, letters are fanned out. Dolls lie, ribbons untied, dresses unravelled. Maud and Roland look up at Si George.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Sir... we found letters from Ash and Christabel --

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: This could change everything -- Sir George points his hunting gun at them.

dialogues.speaker: SIR GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hands up --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roland stands outside, whistling. Waiting for the taxi. Inside -- Maud descends the staircase, sees Sir George in the hall on the telephone. Maud enters --

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: where the letters lie on a mound of yellowing newspapers. Lady Joan greets her sympathetically.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Once it's known these letters exist, everyone will be at your door. Everyone. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LADY JOAN
dialogues.text: Oh, dear... Sir George has a fizzing temper. I'm sorry you have to go. From outside, the taxi BEEPS its HORN. Roland waves to Maud.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: So am I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VOOM, VOOM -- ! Maud REVS up her CAR outside the church where they left it. She pulls out past the taxi which dropped them. Beside her, Roland looks downcast.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: They must be worth a fortune.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: We both had the same instinct. To play them down. Cropper would love to get his hands on them. Do you think we should tell him -- ?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: No -- they'd be in New Mexico tomorrow. He's have to sit on them. Or his whole theory about Ash would be blown away --

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Sir George would be a lot richer. He could mend that house --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I don't know why I feel so possessive about the damned things. They're not mine.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: We found them. And they're private. They're love letters. I'll bet Sir George will sell them... A moment passes. Roland is agitated. He turns to Maud.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: We should make a pact. If one of us finds out any more, he or she tells the other, and no one else. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Maud comes to a crossroads. Left to Lincoln, right to the North. She pauses. Then revs up, sets off. Roland expects to turn left -- to Lincoln. She turns right.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: You went the wrong way.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: We're not going back to Lincoln.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Where are we heading?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Whitby... (beat) We have to find out. Did Christabel go there with Ash? Maud stares at Roland. HOLD ON his expression. As the b.g whizzes past --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An intense sound of WHEELS POUNDING a CLICKETY-CLACK rhyt -- a relentless HISS of STEAM and ROARING FIRE, that burs into a PIERCING WHISTLE -- that tears through time, as --

dialogues.speaker: DAY, (1859)
dialogues.text: Black smoke billows in a hellish cloud, as an iron juggernaut zooms on, landscape zips past a window at breakneck speed, as -- in DAZZLING VIVID COLOR --
