dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: looks out of a window, with a patch of warm breath. A gloved hand wipes through the haze to reveal, in the reflection, Christabel's face in bright sunlight. Both nervous, they sit opposite one another. Both with books upon their knees, Ash suddenly looks up. He has been planning his speech --

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: Forgive this boldness. What I do not know is... whether you wish to travel as my wife. It is a large step -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL
dialogues.text: I want to be with you. I am quite happy to be called your wife. That is what I had understood I -- we -- had decided.

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: You must not regret this.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL
dialogues.text: Of course I shall regret. So will you, will you not? But that is of no importance at this time. Silence. Then from his pocket, a box: inside, a gold signet ring.

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: I hope you will accept this ring.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL
dialogues.text: My resolution was as strong as yours. She produces her own ring, jade with initial "C." They smile. Ash peels off her glove. He pushes his ring over hers.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL
dialogues.text: So... it is done. Ash holds onto her hand. Suddenly with a WHOOSH of smoke the TRAIN plunges into flickering darkness of a tunnel. A presses her hand to his lips. Shards of sunlight flicker like a kinematoscope on his face, Ash lets her fingers fa Then -- into light again -- Ash turns her leather glove i his hands, smoothing its soft leather pockets back into shape like a fetish. Staring at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Late sun. A white hotel, perched on a cliff looking out t sea. As if in a vivid dream -- Ash and Christabel dismoun from a horse-drawn carriage. The hotelier MRS. CAMMISH organizes the baggage: hatboxes, trunks, collecting boxes nets, writing desks. Which are carried upstairs, as -- As and Christabel go to a window. A view over cliffs, of gre sea.

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: There. The German sea. Like steel, with life in it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL
dialogues.text: It reminds me of the Breton coast. Which is in some sense my home. It's so changeable. Blue and clear one day, the next dark and wild.

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: (awkwardly) I -- we -- must go there too. There are so many places. Even around here. Such curious northern names. Ugglebarnby. Jugger Howe. Howl Moor --

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL
dialogues.text: On the map, I saw one. The Boggle Hole. She starts to laugh. Ash smiles too.

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: The Boggle Hole... (laughs too) Do you like the sound of that? Then we shall go there. Ash says it agreeably. Christabel relaxes a little.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL
dialogues.text: I should like that. Very much. Outside, a wind blows in from the sea, as -- END _OF FLASHBACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: outside a picture window, a tall TREE RUSTLES in the wind In a large Victorian room now with modern furniture -- Maud and Roland at a table, busy with piles of books and notes. Map open beside Cropper's biography of Ash, Roland jots down names... Boggle Hole.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: There's a place on the map, the Boggle Hole. That's a nice word. Maybe we could go -- (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (off Maud deep in her book) Found anything?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: (looking up) I've been reading Ash's love poems. Most love poetry is only talking to itself. But Ash wasn't. I think he was talking to her.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: To Ellen --

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: No, Christabel. (beat) I like them now.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I'm glad you like something about him.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I didn't say I didn't like Ash. I only thought Christabel wouldn't like him. I've been trying to imagine him. Them.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: They must have been in an extreme state. A moment of madness brought them here, threw their lives up in the air. Just like us!--

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: They were in love.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Of course. Don't you envy them?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I don't know. We never say the word love, do we. It's always sex. We see it everywhere. We say we're driven by desire, but we can't see it as they did. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Sometimes I feel that the best state is to be without desire. I have this image of a clean empty bed in a clean empty room, where nothing is asked or to be asked --

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: That's what I think about too, when I'm alone. The same image. An empty bed in an empty room. AI1l white.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Exactly the same. Outside, a gust of WIND RUSTLES LEAVES. Mrs. Cammish ente with a tray, Maud presses her napkin to her lips, dabs he mouth.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: How strange. Instinctively, Maud stares down at her napkin. In that moment --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON the imprint of her lipstick --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christabel lowers her napkin politely, stares back at Ash seated opposite. As a 19th Century Mrs. Cammish fusses at the table. Now a private dining suite, decorated in Victorian damask finery.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CAMMISH
dialogues.text: Your lady wife is looking a bit peaky, sir. Not eating her food?

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: Soup. Boiled hake and potatoes. Cutlets and peas. Arrowroot molds and treacle tart. We have dined well, Mrs. Cammish. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CAMMISH
dialogues.text: A spot of sea air. That's the tonic for your wife, sir. I can tell, she's a chilly mortal -- Mrs. Cammish breezily removes her tray, exits. Christabel smiles politely, as Ash takes out a thin cigarillo from a silver case.

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: Mrs. Cammish is right. You must enjoy the sea air.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL
dialogues.text: Perhaps it is considered a wifely pursuit. I think Mrs. Cammish considers me lacking in wifely virtues. Ash lights the cigarillo, takes a lung-full of smoke.

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: I care not for such wifely virtue. (beat) Will you go up first, my dear? Christabel stands up, strained but mocking. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL
dialogues.text: If you wish, my dear... Christabel takes a lit candle, exits. Ash walks to the window. Enjoys his cigar smoke curling in front of him, t CRASH of the SEA below, as Mrs. Cammish reappears.

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: Do you have a cognac?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CAMMISH
dialogues.text: Nothing French in this house, sir.

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: Quite so. (to himself, beneath his breath) “Le degout, c'est voir juste. Apres la possession, l'amour voit juste chez les hommes...' -- Balzac.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CAMMISH
dialogues.text: No cognac, and no Balzac, neither, sir. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: (beat) Good night, Mrs. Cammish. Mrs. Cammish exits. Ash blows a last puff of cigar smoke, then --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ash walks down a dark hall, past towering plants, elabora mosaics, to the stairs. Maids dutifully wax wood, shine brass.

dialogues.speaker: . ASH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Dear Ellen... Today I made a curious geological discovery.. Ash mounts stairs, footsteps muffled by carpet. He nears the top, on his face -- dread and wonder. Ash walks down the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: ASH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Adornments may be made here from ancient ammoniate fossils, creatures long dead but not vanished. They are jet black, with a special silver lustre. In this very marvel of science, I now see a perfect miracle...' Two chambermaids walk past Ash, curtseying. Ash stubs out his cigarillo on a brass ashtray. He stands in front of t room, then opens the door --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ash enters a dark, candle-lit room. On a chair sits a -- Crinoline petticoat like a collapsed cage, all steel hoop and straps. To one side, a brass bed: Where Christabel stands, her back to him, arms on the rails, in a corset.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL
dialogues.text: I need some assistance. Ash moves over to her. His fingers pick up fine, long laces; unthreads, trembling over boned silk; he fumbles, drops them. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: I am inexperienced in such matters. Christabel does not look back. She pulls her hair up to reveal the nape of her neck, downy hair by candlelight. A sees the swell of her breasts, as he plants... A kiss upon her bare shoulder. And with a whisper --

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: You are safe with me.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL
dialogues.text: I am not at all safe with you. (beat) But I have no desire to be elsewhere. Ash unthreads the laces. He feels the curve of her waist, her hips. Slowly, as she turns to undo his collar stud, s kisses him on his neck. As ina...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of buttons and laces -- stockings unrolled -- corset remo -- candle blown out --

dialogues.speaker: UPON BED
dialogues.text: Ash embraces her.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL
dialogues.text: Are you afraid?

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: Not now... my white lady, Christabel. Ash takes her in his arms. They lie upon the bed.

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: Do not fight me...

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL
dialogues.text: I must... On a bedside table a candle flame flickers --

dialogues.speaker: . ROLAND, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And is love more Than the kick galvanic...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pool of light from a bedside lamp, as Roland murmurs a poem aloud from a book of Ash's poetry.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: ... Or the thundering roar Of the Ash volcanic, Thrown from some crater Of earth-fire within?' Roland walks over to the bathroom. A heavy, latched door. He knocks, no reply. Then opens the door --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door swings in -- IN SLOW MOTION. Steam gathers in co air. Roland nearly falls over a part-naked figure!-- Maud in a silken robe, who steadies herself on his should Roland throws up a hand, clasps her supple body beneath h robe -- Maud gasps. An electric current between them --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I knocked -- I'm sorry... Roland briefly clutches the silk. He lets it go, as if stung. He sees her hair -- damp, over bare shoulders and neck. Beads of water, running down to her breasts.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: (composing herself) I waited some time for you to use the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: So did I. I was looking for a light

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Well... (closes her robe) no harm done.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: No. Maud -- Roland reaches out, Maud withdraws. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: If we don't find anything, I'm sorry for getting you into this. I know it was my fault.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: It's okay. I don't blame you.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I wanted us to find something, together. I really did. And if we reach a dead end, then...

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I wanted this to happen too. We'll think of something. (beat) Good night. Maud exits, closing the door. Leaving Roland in the foggy steam, looking at himself in the mirror -- in which he se a blurred figure. He wipes away the steam to see a swirl white sheets --

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: In darkness, Ash awakes. Not beside him. He sees her over by a windowseat. In a swirl of sheets, he gets up, goes over. Finds her shaking silently, with tears. He puts out an arm.

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: What is it, my dear?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL
dialogues.text: How can we bear it? For so short a time. How can we sleep this time away?

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: We can pretend that we have all the time in the world.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL
dialogues.text: And every day we shall have less. And then none.

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: Would you rather have had nothing at all?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL
dialogues.text: No. We are here, we are now. Let me hold you... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Christabel caresses Ash. He kisses her neck, her breast.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL
dialogues.text: You will burn me up.

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: Then let us burn until we are both consumed... Ash kisses her. Draws his hand down her body to her breas

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: Now I know you, truly.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL
dialogues.text: Yes, I admit. You know me... Through the open window, a wind blows, ruffling her hair. breeze floating through the room, as --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A breeze wafts through, ruffling her hair, awakening Maud from her dream to hear Christabel's voice... half-dream, half-real.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: Admit. You know me... In pale dawn light, Maud sees letters scattered over her table. Then over by the windowseat -- Christabel sits looking out, head turned away, hair blowi in the breeze... through the window: sea spray crash on rocks: the water resembles flames of fire. Framed in the window with the ghost, the reflection of th leaping flames against her face, Maud gets an epiphany --

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Oh my God... Roland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roland awakes to KNOCKING at his door. Groggily he gets u goes to the door. Opens it to see -- Maud. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: My room. Now. Maud returns swiftly. Roland steps out warily, wondering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roland walks into Maud's room. Sees her staring out of th window. For a moment, he can't see anything. He looks closer at the window.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I saw her.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Who...?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Christabel. Maud moves closer to Roland. Almost touching. As Roland sees traces of a reflection in the window. He turns to he

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: All my life, since I was a child, I've seen her. But never with anyone else. You saw her, didn't you...?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I'm not sure what I saw...

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I saw Blanche that night in Lincoln. That's why I wanted you to go. I thought it was a warning.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: And now?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I don't know. You don't think I'm crazy --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: No, never. Not much, anyway. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But two crazy people are no more use than one. We still have no proof. Now the ghost has vanished, Maud can see out over the bea

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Look. Out there. Roland squints his eyes. Focuses out in the distance: waves crash upon rocky caverns, sun scattering light like flames.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You read Christabel's poem about Melusina --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: But I never finished it. Maud moves closer to the window, entranced by what she se

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: ‘And where the water moved and shook itself A show of leaping flames, of tongues of light -- Roland moves towards her. An idea.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Wait. Say it again. Do it, and I'll recite a line from Ash. (as Maud protests) Just do it -- Now inspired, Roland starts. Suspicious, Maud carries on.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND MAUD
dialogues.text: 'Shall our hearth's ash '... And where the water grow pale or spark in moved and shook waves--' itself!--' FROM Roland's face, PAN ONTO Maud.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND/MAUD
dialogues.text: (together) '-- A show of leaping flames, of tongues of light, A fountain of cold fire, self renewed.' (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Both amazed, as the words coincide.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: The same lines. Word for word.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: They were here. They saw it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: together. They look out to sea. In the window reflection, flames dance off waves as they crash against rocky caverns. Rola and Maud's faces together in the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside his office, Blackadder is hard at work on a footno of an Ash poem (Mummy Possesst). He looks up to see: Fergus. Instinctively, Blackadder puts a hand over his writing.

dialogues.speaker: FERGUS
dialogues.text: I was looking for Roland Michell.

dialogues.speaker: BLACKADDER
dialogues.text: He's on holiday. He asked for a few days off... Never had a holiday before, now that I think of it --

dialogues.speaker: FERGUS
dialogues.text: Maybe this was personal. I was pretty sure Roland was onto something about Christabel La Motte... (as Blackadder raises an eyebrow) But it may have come to nothing. Or he'd have told you.

dialogues.speaker: BLACKADDER
dialogues.text: He probably would.

dialogues.speaker: FERGUS
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Val is eating cornflakes. CATS MEOWING. The DOORBELL RINGS. She goes to answer it. It's Fergus Wolf.

dialogues.speaker: FERGUS
dialogues.text: Hello, my dearest. Is Roland in? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: No. He's gone away for a few days.

dialogues.speaker: FERGUS
dialogues.text: What a pity. I need to get in touch with him rather urgently.

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: He hasn't phoned. I don't know when he's back. I haven't been all that nice to him.

dialogues.speaker: FERGUS
dialogues.text: I see...

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: I don't know what you see, Fergus. You always see a bit more than there is to see. What's up?

dialogues.speaker: FERGUS
dialogues.text: There's something going on I don't understand. Yet. You don't happen to know Maud Bailey? A silence. Now Val is intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: I see... He didn't tell me what he was up to. He knows I'm not interested. But I did have a phone number. For emergencies.

dialogues.speaker: FERGUS
dialogues.text: This could be an emergency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside a restaurant, Mortimer Cropper walks with Hildebr Ash down the street. When he hears a voice behind him.

dialogues.speaker: FERGUS
dialogues.text: Professor Cropper -- (as Cropper and Hildebrand turn 'round) Sorry to interrupt. I was curious if you'd seen Roland Michell recently... (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FERGUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat; catches his breath) I think he may have discovered something. A connection between Ash and the poet Christabel La Motte... Hildebrand and Cropper exchange glances.

dialogues.speaker: CROPPER
dialogues.text: How extraordinary. We were just discussing an enquiry about some letters up in Lincoln -- (giving his full attention) You interest me, Dr. Wolf. Like a cat with the cream, Fergus purrs quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THROUGH the kitchen window, Sir George peers out from beh the curtain to see a swanky Mercedes arrive outside the house. He goes into the hallway, picks up his shotgun, and!--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir George aims his shotgun down its sights at Mortimer Cropper, standing by his Mercedes looking up at the house

dialogues.speaker: SIR GEORGE
dialogues.text: Who the hell are you? Cropper walks forward, holding out his card.

dialogues.speaker: CROPPER
dialogues.text: Professor Mortimer Cropper of the Cropper Foundation, Harmony City, New Mexico. I've come a long way!-- Sir George doesn't take the card. Still aims the gun.

dialogues.speaker: SIR GEORGE
dialogues.text: Go away. What do you want!-- ? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CROPPER
dialogues.text: Don't shoot. I never trouble the truly reluctant. I believe you may be in possession of letters by Randolph Henry Ash. Have you any idea of how much they would be worth?

dialogues.speaker: SIR GEORGE
dialogues.text: Worth?

dialogues.speaker: CROPPER
dialogues.text: In money. In money, Sir George. Sir George's brow creases with thought. The gun lowers.

dialogues.speaker: SIR GEORGE
dialogues.text: English things should stay in England in my view!--

dialogues.speaker: CROPPER
dialogues.text: Understandable. An admirable sentiment. But these days, how relevant is sentiment? Cropper sees the gap, leaps in. He proffers Sir George hi card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roland and Maud at a rocky cavern they glimpsed from the hotel. Maud with scarf covering her hair, suddenly seeing Roland in a new light, as she examines the distinctive, jet-black stones.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Look at these. All shiny and black. No wonder Ash wrote about them.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I wonder if they ever met again...

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: No one knows where Christabel went when Blanche died. She seems to have vanished --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Then it's hopeless. We still need to find real proof Ash and Christabel were here together. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: That could take weeks... (beat) Will you be sorry to go back now?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Will you?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I have the impression both of us will be sorry. Maud looks up at Roland. And as the sunlight reflects on the stones in her hand --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stones in the hand of Christabel, glinting. Ash and Christabel are in a cavern aglow with light. Outside, WAV CRASH against rocks, as Christabel fills her basket with jet-black stones. In a playful, light-hearted mood, Ash nuzzles close to her.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL
dialogues.text: I shall take these home, use them to prop doors, weigh down the sheets of my poem!-- Affectionately, hands intertwined, she teases him.

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: Let me carry them back for you.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL
dialogues.text: (laughingly) I can carry my own burdens.

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: Not while I am here!-- Ash takes the basket. She relents, then suddenly her mood shifts. She looks away saddened, as they head out onto th rocks.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL
dialogues.text: You know that after these few days together! --

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: Let us not think of time!-- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL
dialogues.text: We must part, never look back. It is inevitable, we both know it!--

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: I cannot, will not. I love you!--

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL
dialogues.text: You speak to me of love? You have a wife, sir. Speak to me of her. In sudden fury, the SEA CRASHES against rocks below. Wind buffets them. In anguish, words stick in his throat, tear in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: I have a wife... and I love her. Not as I love you... (he stops; unable to go on) There are good reasons why my love for you need not hurt her. I know this must sound bald and lame. It must be what many men, philandering men, have said before me. I never thought to find myself saying such things. Yet I believe what I have said to be true. I can never tire of you!-- of this!--

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL
dialogues.text: It is in our nature to tire. Fortunately. Let us collude with necessity. Let us play with it... (beat) '... And if we cannot make our sun stand still, yet we will make him run.'

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: A poet after my own heart.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL
dialogues.text: And mine. Though not more beloved than Randolph Henry Ash... She moves towards him. They embrace passionately. From he pocket, Christabel throws a paper out on the wind, flying away !--

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: What is that? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL
dialogues.text: A poem. I was writing it here.

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: Why!-- ? You... are not happy with it?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL
dialogues.text: These feelings!-- I want them to live forever. To survive the few days we have here. She trembles, close to tears. Ash takes her in his arms. And as the wild sea buffets the shore, WAVES CRASHING against rocks!-- HOLD ON the scraps of paper, as they fly on the wind, PAS the tide pools, ACROSS the beach, TOWARDS the seashore, where! -- They scatter across two pairs of feet. One in chic modern sandals, the other wearing old tennis shoes. REVEAL!-- END OF FLASHBACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roland and Maud on the shore. Reluctantly, getting ready go.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I don't know what will happen to me when I get back. I've got no real job. And then there's Val... I've lived with her since university. I owe her so much. But it doesn't work. Not for any good reason. But because...

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I had a relationship like that. We tormented each other. One of those people who as soon as you open your mouth, they say another cleverer, louder thing. Quoting Freud at six in the morning. I felt battered. For no good reason. Roland sees Maud smiling. Fiddling with her head scarf. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Tell me!-- Why do you always cover your hair?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: It's the wrong color. No one believes it's natural. Ata conference once I got accused of trying to please men. So I cut it off. Now it's grown, I put it away.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: You shouldn't. You should let it out.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Why do you say that?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Because if anyone can't see it, they think and think about it, they wonder what it's like...

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Do they?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Yes... Life is so short. It has a right to breathe. Suddenly, Maud unties her head-square, undoes the clips slowly.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You are an odd man.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I'm not making a pass. You know that.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Yes, I do. That's what's so odd. She puts down her head, shakes it.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: That feels better.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: All right. That feels better. A moment between them. Roland is drawn towards her. But up to the cliff, Maud sees a familiar figure appear, wavi at them. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CROPPER
dialogues.text: Hello, down there!-- ! Roland and Maud swivel 'round to see!-- the urbane silhouette of Mortimer Cropper, walking towards them in t sandy cove.

dialogues.speaker: CROPPER
dialogues.text: At last. You're a hard pair to track down!--

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: How did you find us!-- ?

dialogues.speaker: CROPPER
dialogues.text: A little detective work. You're forgetting. I know our dear Randolph better than any of you. Congratulations on your discovery... (beat) Tea, anyone...? Cropper moves up to them, with his shark's grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cropper pours tea for Maud, Roland looks on. Cropper is charmingly proprietorial, gleeful at his new possessions.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: At least Sir George and Lady Joan will get some money --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: But have you read the letters?

dialogues.speaker: CROPPER
dialogues.text: That's not so important. I'll be sending them back to New Mexico for safekeeping. Poor Lord Ash found the news very upsetting. He had a stroke -- (as Roland and Maud react) Hildebrand has stepped in to look after the Ash estate.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: We can't prove it yet. But we think Ash and Christabel came here. Together! -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CROPPER
dialogues.text: Fascinating... (beat; a grin) Perhaps. Perhaps not... Of course, if something did develop between Ash and Christabel, Maud and I would be the natural team to do the research. After all... (puts a proprietorial arm around her) We have a 'special relationship’... Roland picks up the nuance. Cropper turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: CROPPER
dialogues.text: We already fund Maud's work. And with what I know about Ash... I don't think you'll be needed, Dr. Michell. Roland sits, saying nothing. Furious.

dialogues.speaker: CROPPER
dialogues.text: Thanks for your time and energy, Dr. Michell. I'm sure you understand.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I understand. Roland looks at Maud, like a rabbit in the headlights. Sa nothing. Roland gets up, walks off in disgust. Cropper stops Maud following. She turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Now you own the letters you can do what you want -- why do you need me?

dialogues.speaker: CROPPER
dialogues.text: My lawyer tells me Ash wrote a note returning his letters to Christabel's possession. A legal technicality --

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You mean the letters could belong to me?

dialogues.speaker: CROPPER
dialogues.text: Open to dispute. But I'd hate to see you waste money on law suits. So unnecessary. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Maud pulls her hand away from Cropper.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I was worried you were being nice to me. How silly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud follows Roland up to his room. She knocks on his doo

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Roland, let me in --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Go away -- Maud tries the door. To her surprise, it's unlocked. She enters. Finds Roland flinging his books and papers into a bag.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Look at me, Roland --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I can hear you fine --

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I can't back out of this. The center. The students. That's my life --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Good. You're welcome to it --

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I -- we -- need Cropper's money.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: He wants to own everything. Now he does. Including you --

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: So what can we do? If we had any firm proof about Ash and Christabel

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: We could have carried on -- I can't believe you expect me to listen to Cropper's bullshit -- when, on top of everything else -- you slept with this... this cowboy -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Roland finishes his packing, heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Roland, you're jealous. It's nothing --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Nothing?! You're kidding -- one day I'm on the academic scoop of the decade -- the next this necrophiliac ex-boyfriend of yours tells me I'm unemployed --

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You don't even have a job --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I don't even have a life. I wash dishes --

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I thought that was a story -- some wimpish puppy dog trick for sympathy

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I don't need to invent things. I live in a stinking basement, full of cat piss --

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Then you're pathetic, Roland. Go back to your basement, with your books and your dreams and your stupid romantic illusions -- because you don't live in the real world --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I'm glad. I hate the real world. As a concept, it's much overrated. Maud tries to calm it down. Roland heads out the door.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Okay... okay... Listen -- I'll see what I can do. I'll go to London. Stay at Leonora's. Maybe I can persuade Cropper --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Don't bother. I thought we wanted the same thing. Obviously, we don't. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Roland takes his bag, pushes past her. Exits down the corridor. Maud watches him disappear. Behind her, Cropper

dialogues.speaker: CROPPER
dialogues.text: Not your type, Maud. Too weak. Leonora and I would both be devastated. The sound of a TRAIN, WHISTLING through a tunnel, as --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drifting off, Roland sits in his carriage as the train zi through the rolling countryside. In the newspaper, an article: "Ash Letters Rock Literary World" with a picture of... Cropper. The light plays on his face, flickering like a kinematoscope -- As a WHISTLE SHRIEKS and carries over TO --

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: Amid the steam of a train on its platform, Ash and Christabel disembark. His luggage sits awaiting him with porters. He takes Christabel to a carriage, loaded with her cases. Ash helps her up. Holds onto her hand, as she sits down.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL
dialogues.text: I must go.

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: If only... He kisses her hand. Christabel gives a rueful smile.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL
dialogues.text: I am sad we went walking, sir. (beat) Yet sad too, that we are not walking still. She does not withdraw her hand. Ash lets it go. The coachman shuts the door. They stare into each other's eye as the driver cracks his whip and her carriage sets off - Ash stares at the carriage. His eyes moist with tears. As Christabel vanishes into the distance. END OF FLASHBACK.  84.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weary and exhausted, finally home, Roland passes his bicycle, makes his way down his flat. In the corridor, Roland finds Val. With her coat on. A suitcase. And vase, in hand.

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: Hello, Roland. Did you have a good time with Maud Bailey?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I rang and rang you ...

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: I thought if you could vanish, I could. So I did.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: You don't look very angry, Val. Actually, you look happy. Roland looks 'round the flat. Furniture seems to be missing.

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: I decided I could be... (beat) I'm going to live with Euan. The shock, when it comes, is a double whammy: he has no idea.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: A lawyer. In my office. Anything to say?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Er... I'm glad.

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: I hope not altogether glad. Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: In some ways. In others, I'm ina mess.

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: You'll survive, I suppose. The rent's paid until the first of the month. This week, that is. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll leave you the cats... Dry food. And sardines. No tins. And change the tray. Daily... if you can possibly manage. Roland stands in the hallway, Val picks up her suitcase, exits. The door slams. Welcome home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside a studio, a TV panel gets ready to debate the hot literary news. LEONORA STERN, a loud, energetic US femini sits next to Blackadder, in the makeup chair, while Cropp and Hildebrand Ash sit under lights getting ready.

dialogues.speaker: MAKEUP
dialogues.text: Ready, Professor Stern -- ?

dialogues.speaker: LEONORA
dialogues.text: More blush, deary, I can take it -- As an interviewer announces a lead-in, Leonora leans over whispering to Blackadder, hand poised on his thigh.

dialogues.speaker: LEONORA
dialogues.text: You've got to make your Mr. Ash to be the hottest property in town, Professor. Get them by the balls. Give them one sexy thing, you'll do fine!--

dialogues.speaker: BLACKADDER
dialogues.text: One sexy thing. Mmnnn...

dialogues.speaker: LEONORA
dialogues.text: I love the way you talk. By the way... (hand on his thigh) I take it neither of us want Cropper to win this. You may be interested, Professor. I got a letter from a research student in Brittany...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On TV screen!-- a beautiful interviewer, Patel, introduce the panel. As we PULL BACK to see!-- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (on TV) '... The literary world has been rocked by an extraordinary discovery. A panel of experts is here to discuss...' Alone in his apartment!-- Roland glowering at the TV scre A low moan. The cats keep out of his way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watching the same TV program, like two lonely hearts, Mau sits on the sofa in Leonora's. She uncovers a letter on a table. <A French address catches her eye. She reads it avidly.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: (reading aloud) I am currently working on an unpublished writer, Sabine de Kercoz, and have discovered material I believe will be of interest to you. Yours... Dr. Ariane Le Minier...' Maud flicks through Leonora's files. Finds an address. Sh hesitates. INTERCUT between --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taps full on, Roland runs a bath. The noise drowns out TV and phone. His answer machine plays Maud's voice to an empty room.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (on answer machine) ‘ Roland...? Are you there...? Roland, I need to speak to you... I know you don't want to speak to me... But I think I've found another clue... CLICK -- the message breaks off.  87.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO TV
dialogues.text: as each of the panel competes for 15 seconds of fame.

dialogues.speaker: LEONORA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ‘ Of course, from a radical feminist perspective, it was a surprise to learn Christabel might have loved a man!--

dialogues.speaker: BLACKADDER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: A complete shock. It's as if we'd discovered Shakespeare's Dark Lady!-

dialogues.speaker: CROPPER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I don't think we have to rush to conclusions. Nothing happened. To my eyes, this correspondence was a purely literary love affair. Ash was always a complex man. This only proves his moral stance as exemplary. Until Dr. Fergus Wolf and I examine the evidence! --

dialogues.speaker: BLACKADDER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: That's why the letters must stay in our country as part of our heritage!--

dialogues.speaker: PATEL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (to Hildebrand Ash) With your father now ill, doesn't that question come to you?

dialogues.speaker: HILDEBRAND, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: : After a hundred years, some of us feel the time is right to let Ash enter the modern world!--

dialogues.speaker: CROPPER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Now is the time to bring other valuable parts of Ash's legacy into the public eye... ON Cropper's smile --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next morning. Darkness. Roland lies in bed, asleep. Curtains drawn. The PHONE RINGS, wakes him. Roland gets u to answer it. A friendly voice. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Roland... are you there...?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Beatrice...? I'm glad it's you. I suppose you saw those vultures on

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up in the old Ash house, now a museum, shelves are filled with books, papers, portraits. Glass cases of specimens. Amid a huge box-file, Beatrice takes shelter. On the phon

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: ... Yes. Are you alright? I'm over at the Ash Museum -- Blackadder's been in a fearful rage. Says you've been doing things behind his back --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Right now I hate Blackadder -- I hate Ash -- I hate the whole Ash factory --

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: He's screaming for a copy of Mrs. Lees's book, with a description of the Ash seance --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: The seance? Why?

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: Cropper's onto something. He's checking up on Ash's whereabouts in 1860. He's desperate. My filing system is his last hope. I can't find a copy anywhere. Maybe you could help --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Hmm... I don't know... It's called The Shadowy Portal, isn't it? Roland looks distractedly at his piles of books. Around t apartment, books on shelves. On window ledges. In boxes.. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: Yes. Call me if you have a brainwave. My life will be miserable otherwise.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I'll have a think. I'm sure I've seen it recently... 'Bye. CLICK. Roland puts down the phone. But he's already gripped by an idea. He runs his fingers along the shelves Scanning for a title. He moves to another pile, rapid search --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: (from memory) The Shadowy Portal... An autobiographical reminiscence... by Mrs. Hella Lees... Roland darts from shelf to box, repeating his mantra --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: the London Library copy... Until like a divining rod, his hands guide him to a pile books behind a box. Roland dives in, brings out -- A book. It's old. With gilded leaves, an embossed dove on the cover. And in the frontispiece -- an oval photograph Mrs. Lees. Roland leafs through the pages --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: The seance... of course, the seance... He takes the copy, sits down in an armchair. Finds a chapter, headed "A Mummy Possest?" As he starts to read, cat jumps up, curls 'round him. Over Roland, reading --

dialogues.speaker: ASH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: “I wish to see the lady of the house... Mrs. Lees... Please, allow me in... No one must know... No one...

dialogues.speaker: CHELSEA
dialogues.text: A velvet curtain sweeps open to reveal -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ash in black, wearing a face-mask. He enters the chamber, lit by a strange, violet ray from a lantern. A masked woman -- MRS. HELLA LEES -- clad in jewels, lead him over towards --

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LEES
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, members of the Vestal Lights, let the seance begin... A circular table: seven ladies, four men; they clasp hand Ash takes a seat in the circle.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LEES
dialogues.text: (to spirit world) We are ready to receive you, if your spirit stands at the threshold, we ask you to reveal yourself. Is anybody there...? Mrs. Lees taps the table. Ash scans the circle, his eyes hit those of a woman opposite. A sharp intake of breath a

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LEES
dialogues.text: I feel hands. As cold as ice... The table vibrates. Ash watches Mrs. Lees shake uncontrollably. A spirit voice speaks through her --

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LEES
dialogues.text: “Do not force me...' (as herself) Who is it? (as voice) “Nobodaddy...' Ash sees a halo of electromagnetic force like fire surrou Mrs. Lees. Suddenly Ash feels a TAPPING shake the table. breeze lifts skirts. Ash hears a WOMAN SOB, then LAUGHTER

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LEES
dialogues.text: There is a hostile presence in the room. Is there a spirit who wishes to speak? The sound of RUNNING WATER. Ash looks at the woman opposite: and recognizes Christabel, who speaks in a trance, a spirit voice possesses her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: gl.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL
dialogues.text: (in a spirit voice) “Remember the stones...! (in her own voice) Where are you? (in the spirit voice) “I bring gifts...!

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LEES
dialogues.text: She is possessed. A spirit is with us... Ash wants to go over to her. But the circle's hands hold onto him. He hears RUSHING WATER boom LOUDER, then sees -- A vision of a white hand carrying a white wreath, hanging from the chandelier by threads. The circle clasps hands again --

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LEES
dialogues.text: Let her go... the spirit has entranced her... Do not wake her... As Blanche's spirit manifests itself --

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LEES
dialogues.text: You bring a message of love...? But an ELECTROMAGNETIC CURRENT CRACKLES, holds Ash's hand fast. Ash struggles to get free --

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: I must speak... Ash moves towards Christabel. But the wreath tangles him threads like a web. He tries to break free, but ghostly hands wrap around his throat --

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: Away, foul spirit. I beg you -- Ash turns to see a ghostly face of Blanche. In rage, he raises the wreath in his hands. Mrs. Lees pleads --

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LEES
dialogues.text: -- Don't break the spell -- her spirit will be harmed forever -- ! But Ash hurls the wreath away, a SHRIEK as Blanche's spir disappears. Ash rushes at Christabel, who almost faints i her trance. He holds her in his arms, removes her mask -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: Speak, I beg you... I came to France... you turned me away, my darling... For God's sake, answer... tell me the truth... I must know... Weeping, Ash cradles Christabel in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: Where is she...? Is she not dead? Tell me... Tell me what you have done... Ash bends to hear Christabel's whisper.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL
dialogues.text: You have made me... a murderess. Christabel collapses. Guests try to pull Ash away from he He howls in pain and rage --

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: Dead...? No-o-oo -- !! Ash pushes over a candle flame, which spills over. Mrs. Lees comes to her senses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: around Ash a fiery halo of red.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LEES
dialogues.text: Sir, you are a demon... Go now... Ash stands up, a force of red light surrounding him. He looks at his own hands, sees them -- smeared in transluce blood. END OF FLASHBACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a cavernous library lined with ancient tomes, at a lon oak table, Maud finishes work for the day. Around her, nu put away leather volumes, ready to close up. Maud picks u her notebooks, piles of photocopied documents. Exits into  93.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cloistered courtyard of a medieval convent. RAIN POURS down. She passes nuns scurrying about their business, sheltered by the old cloister roofs. In her brisk, modern clothes, Maud is a surreal contrast, as she emerges to se A young, chic French scholar, DR. ARIANE LE MINIER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside a battered Renault, WINDSCREEN WIPERS SLOOSH BACK FORTH, as Le Minier and Maud drive into a small town.

dialogues.speaker: LE MINIER
dialogues.text: When I sent my discoveries to Professor Stern, I hoped she would notify you. I am a great admirer of your writings on Christabel.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You couldn't have been more helpful, Ariane.

dialogues.speaker: LE MINIER
dialogues.text: The photocopier is a great democratic invention, no...? As Le Minier talks, Maud stares through windscreen wipers in a blur of rain and glass, she suddenly sees --

dialogues.speaker: AT SIDE OF ROAD
dialogues.text: Two bedraggled figures, one of them Christabel, distresse and crying, holding out her hands. Maud focusses on her a the CAR ZOOMS past -- Their eyes meet -- as --

dialogues.speaker: LE MINIER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We should share our information, should we not? Is it not a feminist principle, cooperation?

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Maud snaps back, answers with a smile. Le Minier buzzes along the country roads, heading for the nearby small tow  94.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain pours down. Le Minier sets Maud down nearby her hote in a provincial seaside town, near a sandy bay and dark s As Maud runs to the entrance, she sees someone sheltering from the elements. Hunched over, slumped, drenched by rai On closer inspection, she sees -- Roland. Shocked at firs she warms to a smile. As Roland looks up, anorak collar pulled up. And through the rain, they rush together, thro arms 'round each other. Then slowly pull apart --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: We must be mad.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Of course we are mad. Roland pauses as if about to say something important. And sneezes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In her bedroom, Roland sits, feet in a bowl of steaming water. He wraps a towel 'round his head, as he and Maud share their discoveries.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: She was there. Christabel was there at the seance. But Ash was so full of rage --

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Or grief. He believed Christabel was responsible for someone's death. The question is -- “Who?!

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Blanche, of course. You said no one knew where Christabel was when Blanche committed suicide.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Until now. That's what I found from Leonora's letter. Christabel had family in Brittany. A young cousin who wrote a journal. A French researcher found fragments of poems by Christabel dated Spring 1860. This is where she was. Until now, nobody knew... Maud takes the towel, rubs Roland's hair dry. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I wish nobody knew where I was.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Me too. I've lied shamelessly to Leonora. I even stole Dr. Le Minier's address.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: All scholars are a bit crazy. Roland sneezes, blows his nose. He's in a bad way, his towel like a turban, balanced on his head.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Roland, you said Ash came to France. When exactly -- ?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Spring, 1860...

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Exactly?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Around... March.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: So think about it, Roland. (Roland is blank) How long is that after Ash and Christabel were in Whitby? Under his turban, Roland does his sums. Maud knows the answer.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: About... eight... no... Nine months.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Nine months. Maud stares at Roland. Who gasps with surprise. As he dries his hair, he freezes. A sudden realization --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: A... child.

dialogues.speaker: VARIOUS SHOTS
dialogues.text: Out walking -- two figures, Christabel with her young cousin, SABINE. Christabel's pale face, unwell, under strain. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL
dialogues.text: And how do you think things are with me, cousin Sabine? Christabel turns her face away. Sabine sees she is weepin

dialogues.speaker: CONVENT
dialogues.text: Christabel knocking on the door. Then INSIDE the courtyar A cloak conceals her figure. INSIDE an office, a nun pull aside the cloak. Pregnant. Then --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: If there was a baby, did it survive?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Though if it survived --

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Ash could have believed she was trying to speak to her child in the seance.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Her dead child. But if Ash ever knew --

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: In the records of the Convent, they record a visit by a gentleman who answers Ash's description. He was turned away. They never spoke again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud and Roland go downstairs, peering over the bannister Suddenly, they freeze. In the lobby of the hotel, they se Leonora Stern with Blackadder, canoodling fondly.

dialogues.speaker: IN LOBBY
dialogues.text: Roland and Maud overhear Leonora with Blackadder.

dialogues.speaker: LEONORA
dialogues.text: I don't understand why Maud dashed off without a word. That letter from Le Minier was mine, after all. We were good friends... (beat) Perhaps your Roland Michell is some kind of macho boss-man.

dialogues.speaker: BLACKADDER
dialogues.text: He's not forceful. It's his major failing.

dialogues.speaker: LEONORA
dialogues.text: Then it must be love.

dialogues.speaker: BACK ON STAIRS
dialogues.text: Maud and Roland sneak back to their room.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Should we go and confront them? Maud puts out both her hands. Roland takes them.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I think we should. And I think we can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Leonora and Blackadder, in bright leisurewear and sunglasses, stride out from the hotel. Roland and Maud sneak out of the entrance into -- a taxi CAB. Which ZOOMS off at high speed, passing them on the esplanade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At a cross-channel port, an overnight ferry in dock. Rola and Maud walk up the gangway, into the passenger sections

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the tiny cabin, Roland and Maud put down their bag and investigate. A white room. Twin bunks. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Shower. They seem light-headed and giddy. Roland takes stock.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: These are clean narrow white beds. Just like we always wanted.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: So they are. Do you prefer top or bottom?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I don't see that it matters. And you?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I'll take the top. Suddenly, perfectly aware of the absurdity and sexual ambiguity of it all, they laugh out loud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Night time. Outside, the WATER HISSES and PRICKLES. Dark waves carved by the huge boat... as down below --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a low light, Roland and Maud lie together, back to bac on the bottom bunk, ankles overlapping. Maud is reflectiv muted. Neither can sleep.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I feel sad about Christabel's baby...

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: We don't know it was dead.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I can't help thinking... if it wasn't destined to die, why did she run away? Why didn't she stay where she was safe?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Maybe she meant no one to know what happened. Not even us... Roland turns toward Maud. Who is still turned away. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I think I've lost everything I've ever had or cared about. Ash. My job. Even Val now...

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: She walked out. I should feel frightful. But if I had to tell the truth... (beat) I want... that life, Maud. Ash and Christabel's. I'm not afraid to admit it. Roland puts his hand on Maud's, looks directly at her. Hi face next to hers, a moment of truth.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I know it sounds crazy --

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I thought you were like me. You wanted the empty room.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I did. Now I'm not so sure.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: No, please -- I can't -- I don't want to lose myself. Do you understand how important that is?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Yes -- but -- to live life so powerfully. Does anyone do that anymore?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Not me -- too romantic. Life isn't like that.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Maybe that's why we read books, you and me. Silence overtakes them. Comfortable and safe, the swell o the SEA hushes them. The WIND outside CARRIES OVER INTO -  100.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the open window, a lace curtain billows in the breeze. Ellen closes the window. She walks into the library, a FI ROARS. At a desk, Ash looks through a microscope: At a dead butterfly. Its intricate patterns. A pin is poised over the sample. Yet his mind is on something else. He gets up moves behind her. Ellen stops.

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: Ellen, I have something I must tell you. Ellen turns to him. Ash pauses, then words tumble out.

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: For the last year, I have been in love with another woman. I could say it was a sort of madness. A possession, as by demons. A kind of blinding. At first it was only letters -- and then -- in Yorkshire -- I was not alone --

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: I know. Ellen looks up at Ash, his proud crest fallen.

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: How long?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: I was told. I had a visitor. Ellen unlocks a drawer. Brings out the original copy of Ash's poem, in an envelope addressed to "Miss La Motte, Bethany..."

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: The original version of your poem. Certain passages are superior, I think, to what you now have here. (beat) I sensed a new inspiration. A muse. As I would care to inspire you, were I a poet. Silence. Ash is speechless, deep in thought. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1ol.

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: If I had not told you about this -- about Miss La Motte -- would you have restored this to me?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: I think not. How could I? But you have told me.

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: Miss Blanche Glover gave you this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up at the window, the lace curtain flutters out on the breeze. Inside, in the reception room -- a letter is flung onto a table.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: She wrote twice. And came here... On the envelope: Ash's handwriting: Inside, a manuscript of a poem. Addressed to "Christabel La Motte..." Ellen stares at it. She turns away from -- Blanche. Who paces up and down in her neat worn boots, clasping and unclasping her hands.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCHE
dialogues.text: Your own happiness is ruined, is a lie. You could help me if you chose. We were so happy -- From the table, Ellen picks up a bell. She rings it.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: I can do nothing about your happiness, Miss Glover. Please leave my house. A maid comes to the door. Ellen stares at her. Blanche pauses. Then exits. Ellen turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ash before Ellen, stumbling to find words.

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: I do not know what to say, Ellen. I do not expect to see her -- Miss La Motte again. We were agreed that this one summer must see the end -- of... (voice trembles) the end. And even if that were not so -- she has vanished, she has gone away -- Ellen hears Ash's pain, notes it, says nothing. A silence

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: You must be angry -- distressed --

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Not angry. I know how gentle and patient you have been with me. For I have never been a real wife to you...

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: Ellen, do not --

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: If I have not proffered the proper intimacy between husband and wife, that is my regret, Randolph. (beat) Yet you have never ceased to love me. falls between them.

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: You are my wife, Ellen. I shall always love you.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Then, as you have forgiven me, so I shall forgive you. Ellen wipes a tear from her eye, looks up at Ash.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: It is a question of silence. Let us not talk of it again, Randolph. Ellen gently responds, touching his hand. NOISES FADE IN from a MODERN-DAY STATION, as we --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A busy train station. Roland and Maud emerge on a platfor push through crowds. Roland looks up to see: a wild figur dashing up the platform: Beatrice, waving frantically.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Beatrice -- ? Beatrice arrives, huffing and puffing, out of breath.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: Oh dear. I am sorry. You may think I'm mad, or bad, or presumptuous -- I could only think of you --

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Dr. Nest -- Beatrice -- please...

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: I wouldn't have come unless you seemed to care about her --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: About...

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: Her... Ellen. (beat; as if it was obvious) I have to tell you both something. It's urgent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back indoors, a cup of tea freshly made, Beatrice is back under control. Roland and Maud listen, as Beatrice calms down.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: Mortimer Cropper was here today. Looking at sections of Ellen's journal.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: About Blanche's visit? Beatrice looks at them both. Very serious.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: No. About Ash's funeral. He brought young Hildebrand Ash. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm absolutely certain Cropper wants to open up Ash's tomb. He wants to find out what is in the box.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: What box?

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: Ellen's.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: The one Ellen buried in Ash's tomb. Maud sits down with Roland, now surrounded by Beatrice an Maud.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: I don't know what to do. They all dislike me so -- they think Ellen's diary is unimportant. I've been thinking... (beat) Ellen wrote to baffle us.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: She wrote so much. To throw us off the scent. (beat) I believe she must have known if there was a child... what happened to it. How it died. That's why she buried the truth in a box... From a leather portfolio, Beatrice removes an old scrap o paper.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: She left this scrap of paper in her desk when she died. I'm sure Ellen knew the scavengers would come -- sooner or later... (reciting from memory ) “What shall I be without you? My Randolph now is gone...' Beatrice stands in front of the glass cases, from inside, Roland and Maud hear a FLUTTERING sound. As if the BUTTERFLIES are suddenly alive, fluttering wings, trying escape, as -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: With Maud, he follows Beatrice towards the old bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: Follow me... Beatrice walks into the old bedroom, past the glass cases and portraits, the aquarium and books of the first dreaml shot -- As if Beatrice has become Ellen's ghost...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen leans over her dying husband. Ash lies in bed, propped up on pillows. He is dying.

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: Forty-four years with no anger. I do not think many husbands and wives can say as much... (beat) It cannot be helped. Do you think, after death, we continue...? Ellen bows her head, begins to weep.

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: Do not cry. I am not sorry. I have not -- done nothing, you know. I have lived. Ellen sees Ash clutching in his hand a gold pocket watch: long, plaited chain of gold hair tied around it.

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: Do not let me be picked by vultures. Burn what they should not see... Ellen unwinds her hair from his hands. A KNOCK at the doo As she gets up to go, Ash moans deliriously --

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: Summer fields... in a twinkling of an eye, I saw her. I should have looked after her. How could 1? I could only hurt her... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: You saw who? In the summer fields? You saw who, Randolph?

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: (after a pause) I... forgot... Ash falls back asleep, his hand clutches the watch with t golden hair which Ellen will also later bury. Ellen goes the door, opens it to a doctor. As he enters, Ellen turns back -- To look at her husband -- a moan as she sees he is -- Dead. A wind blows her candle, smoke past tearful eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON a ROARING FIRE, flames burn up papers. Ellen watches, throws more on. At her husband's desk --

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: What shall I be without you? (NOTE: The one Roland and Maud now read, lies on the desk She takes a packet of letters, tied with ribbons. She hesitates. Instead of throwing them on the fire, Ellen walks toward box...

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ~-- My Randolph now is gone. Tomorrow we will set out together on his last blind journey...' She unlocks the box, removes an envelope, addressed to "Randolph Ash." The broken seal recognizable as Christabel's: a crest of arms, a shield held up by a unicorn and centaur. Ellen goes to the bed-stand: a pocket watch with a plait golden hair wrapped around the chain-ring.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ... And these letters and mementoes -- why do I choose to put them up, in their sealed enclosure...? On the desk beside Ellen's note, an open box. She hesitates, holding the letters in her hand, then --  107.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As in the opening -- the same box. Closed and sealed in Ellen's hands. PULL BACK to reveal: mourners in black. Ellen walks forward with the box --

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: '... I want them to have a sort of duration. A demi-eternity...' Places the box in the mausoleum near Ash's coffin.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: '... And if the seekers dig them out again...?' On cue, the GATES CLOSE WITH a THUD. The box now locked a sealed in the mausoleum --

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: '... Then justice will perhaps be done to her when I am not here to see it.' END OF FLASHBACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the shadowy twilight, Beatrice looks out from the darkness. She takes back her precious note from Roland an Maud.

dialogues.speaker: . ROLAND
dialogues.text: Justice will perhaps be done to her.' Who did she mean?

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: I've asked myself that question all these years. A scholar's lifetime...

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: If Cropper digs it up, he can keep the truth hidden forever.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: So what can we do? We'd need to catch him in the act --

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: Or get to the box before him --

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: You mean, break in... to the tomb? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: I know it sounds... barbaric.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: This note you've shown us -- no one else has seen it?

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: (shaking her head) No one else has asked. They don't think Ellen is important. But, you see? She is. Roland looks at Maud, an unaccustomed glint in his eye.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Then we need to go now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An 18th Century inn with mossy roof and orchard, near a village church. Beneath a large tree, the dark shape of a Mercedes. Trunk open, with Cropper and Hildebrand inspecting lights, shovels, ropes.

dialogues.speaker: HILDEBRAND
dialogues.text: I suppose we could leave false clues. Blame it on the Satanists. A black mass or something... Hildebrand snorts with laughter. Cropper frowns.

dialogues.speaker: CROPPER
dialogues.text: I am not a common thief. It's only that box -- the thought of it decaying in the ground -- the thought of perhaps never knowing -- He closes the trunk. Cropper and Hildebrand walk over to the inn, and enter, VOICES CARRYING OVER inside --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On hilly roads, Maud drives her car through thickening mi Roland at her side. They pass the trip in silence, each waiting for the other to speak.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You packed the things? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: The crowbar?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Yes. The crowbar.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: We might need it. Aren't you worried -- ? Maud glances over towards him, her excitement palpable. Then -- she swerves to avoid a truck; Roland winces, sigh

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I don't worry about anything. Not now. At the moment, I feel all -- clear in the head -- if you know what I mean. They sit in silence as she zooms down a narrow side stree through the fog. Then down a steep hill with trees on bot sides.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Roland, I'm sorry how it turned out.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: For who?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You. And me. I think I was afraid.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I don't think so. Not you. Of what?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Of falling in love with you.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I didn't know you wanted to... That's over now, anyway. I don't want you to love me.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You don't? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: No. Too complicated. I can't think about 'us' anymore. The fog grows thicker, as if they're driving back in time --

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: Illuminated in a flash of lightning: as the beginning -- FOOTSTEPS. A hand KNOCKS on a door. Three knocks.

dialogues.speaker: MAID, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: Mrs. Ash...? END OF FLASHBACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roland slams on the brakes. Swirling fog clears to reveal A hound like Christabel's companion from Seal Court, in t road. The animal vanishes behind another cloud of fog. Roland and Maud drive slowly forward. The fog grows more misty -- COVERING the SCREEN as we --

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: The same hand KNOCKING on the door. Details become cleare as we REVEAL. Again the KNOCKING. A hushed servant's voice:

dialogues.speaker: MAID, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: Mrs. Ash... a letter. Sound of RAIN ON GLASS. HORSES' HOOVES ON COBBLESTONES. The door opens to reveal Ellen, facing her young MAID.

dialogues.speaker: MAID
dialogues.text: A lady called Miss La Motte came to the door. She gave me this letter for your husband. She said it was very important. Ellen takes an envelope from the girl's hand, closes the door.  111.

dialogues.speaker: LETTER
dialogues.text: The coat of arms from Seal Court. In Christabel's handwriting: "To Randolph Henry Ash Esq -- Most Urgent." And her name: "From: Christabel La Motte, Seal Court, Lincolnshire." Ellen takes the letter. Slowly, softly, she walks into th

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Where Ash lies in bed, deathly ill. As Ellen picks up the letter, she holds it to her, unable to let it go -- Poised over a candle's flame --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peering through the bar window, Roland sees Cropper eatin and drinking with Hildebrand and Fergus. He sneaks back t Maud, standing by Cropper's Merc.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: They're all there. Cropper, Hildebrand, even Fergus.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Roland, did you bring a knife?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Yes. Do you need it?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Yes, I do. Roland brings out a knife from his bag. Without warning, Maud takes it over to the Merc, stabs one tire. Then the other. AIR RUSHES OUT. The TIRES PUNCTURE fast.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: All right -- shall we? Roland stares at Maud and the knife. Both is disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud and Roland pull up on the hill near the cemetery gat On the gates, a sign: "STRICTLY NO ADMITTANCE" Nearby a large wall, where they place a ladder. Up over the wall, into the cemetery they go. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: lle.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Walking through the graveyard, ‘round long curved avenues the necropolis. As if, from the tombstones and graves, voices fill the air.

dialogues.speaker: . CHRISTABEL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: My dear, my dear...' HOLD ON Roland and Maud as they disappear up the hill, in the gloomy darkness among the trees waving in the breeze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Near the mausoleum, the tomb awaits, the box inside.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I ask for your forgiveness for intruding on you at this time. I am told you are gravely ill...'

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE CABINET
dialogues.text: HOLD ON the letter, its flap of envelope open. We hear a voice, MOVE TOWARDS it, until white paper FILLS the SCREE

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ... I have writ down some things I dearly wish you should know...'

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: As in Roland and Maud's earlier journey, we CLIMB UP -- A winding spiral staircase leading to a tower bedroom, wa now freshly-pained, Christabel's dolls -- where Maud and Roland find the letters a century later -- kept neatly on their bed. A woman sits at her desk, talking softly as she composes letter. It is Christabel, now an old woman, in her 60s.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL
dialogues.text: I sit here like an old witch in a tower. You will say to me, it should have been told, twenty-eight years ago. I know -- I have known for these many years -- that I have done you wrong. Yet, my guilt for all that happened made it impossible...' (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Christabel drifts to the window. Golden summer sun floods in.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL
dialogues.text: The truth is, that you have a daughter, who is well, and married, and the mother of a wonderful boy.' She looks down from her isolation onto the grass knoll below, so well-kept in its day. A beautiful woman in her late 20s, MAIA BAILEY, plays with her baby boy.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL
dialogues.text: ... She is beautiful, and called Maia, and resembles, I think, both her parents, neither of which she knows to be her parents...! Christabel turns from the window, lost in her memories.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: Christabel's memories. We are FLYING OVER rugged winter terrain before a farmhouse, TOWARDS a barn in Brittany, decades ago.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: . We agreed to leave each other and never look back. And for pride's sake, and yours, I resolved to keep my side of it. When I discovered my condition, Blanche and I quarrelled bitterly. I could not come to you. So I made arrangements -- I found a place to go in France - - but you came searching after me...' The doors of the barn open for us, and we CREEP PAST cows and mules that stare TOWARDS us.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: So I fled, I fled...' We REACH a haystack in the back, where the squatting Christabel trembles in agony. CIRCLE AROUND, we see her sweat-drenched face.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I concluded that no decent refuge remained fit for me...' She opens her mouth to scream, as --  114.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ... And when I thought of poor Blanche...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone, Blanche sewing pockets of a dress: stones (from Whitby) expertly bound with needle and thread...

dialogues.speaker: ON TABLE
dialogues.text: A suicide note in Blanche's writing, placed on a desk: "T whom it may concern..." Weighed down by a stone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upon a bridge, Blanche looks into swirling waters of a da river. In her pockets, silvery-black stones sewn in by thread. As she walks to the precipice of the bridge, and jumps --

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I knew I had killed her...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the bottom of the river, Blanche tumbles, bubbles slow expiring from her mouth. Her body weighed down by the fossil stones, she floats eerily in the cold darkness...

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I could not face the world. Nor you...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a dark cloak, Christabel, alone, facing out to sea. At her lowest ebb. Distraught, tears streaming down her cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I felt haunted, cursed, and alone...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Despite the memory, Christabel's face is calm and peacefu

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ... So I gave dear Maia to my sister Sophie Bailey, who brought her up as her own...' Christabel wanders into the shadows of her room, which ar covered with stacks of papers. A lifetime of words.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ... Now I want to make amends, let these ghosts rest in peace. I have flown about the battlements of this stronghold, crying on the wind of my need to see and feed and comfort my child, who knows me not and -- to whom can I say this, but you? -- who loves me not...' She returns to the window.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And yet, she is so happy. Ah, but if you were here, you would see how I dare not disturb her peace...!'

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAIA'S FACE
dialogues.text: She looks up, perhaps her eyes meet Christabel's. But the young mother quickly averts them.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ... I have been angry for so long - - with all of us, with you, with Blanche, with my poor self... and now, near the end, I think of you with clear love...' She moves to her desk, signs her name to the letter, then picks up a small art-nouveau picture frame. She removes t photo.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: : I send you her picture. She will have nothing of her strange name, and prefers to be called May, which suits her...'  116.

dialogues.speaker: PHOTO
dialogues.text: of a woman on her wedding day. Original of the photo on Maud's mantelpiece, her great-great-grandmother, May.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTABEL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ... Did we not -- did you not flame, and I catch fire? Is that not fine? Shall we survive and rise from our ashes...?'

dialogues.speaker: ON CHRISTABEL'S FACE
dialogues.text: as she prepares to part with her photo. A burst of sunshi surges through the window. She is consumed in white. As the light slowly fades, we HOLD ON photo, but now it's old, faded, and in muddy hand END OF FLASHBACK. DISSOLVE THROUGH and REVEAL --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain starts. The sun is about to rise. Roland and Maud si at the graveyard by the mausoleum. On the ground --

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: (reading letter) ... And so, "in the calm of mind, all passion spent," I thank God -- if there must be a dragon -- that he was you.' The box has been opened, the letter (with crest) sits out its envelope, photos in their hands, watch with its braid lock of golden hair. Roland holds it against Maud's own hair.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: It's her. May. She was...

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
