dialogues.text: My great-great-grandmother, yes. May...

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Now I know why they left all this -- the clues, the poems, the letters. They wanted you to know, Maud. They left them for you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Holding the old crumpled pictures of May, Maud is overcom

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: She looks like Christabel. You can see it.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: She looks like you. She looks like Randolph Henry Ash, too.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: So I look like Ash? A hint of lightness. Roland smiles, gently touches her face.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I would never have thought of it. But yes -- here, at the corner of the eyebrow -- the edge of the mouth

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Now you see it, you'll always see it

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I'll never be free of it.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: No. We'll never be free. Maud smiles too, looks up at Roland, as if for the first time. Roland reaches out to her, holds her close to him.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Maud... I... love you so much... The ice queen melts. Maud buries her face, tears fall.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I just love you. That's how it is. Maud raises her arms to him, his hands stroke her wet hai tracing the curves of her shivering body. As --

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: The worst possible way then. They pull away for an instant. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Yes, total obsession. The worst... They move closer. Roland knows her heart is barely triumphing over her fear. Fighting every inch of the way, Maud softly brings her lips to his. A heartbeat away from a... Long, lingering kiss. Until -- Maud opens her eyes, looks up slowly. And behind Roland, sees -- over the brow of the hill, a familiar figure: Beatrice. Smiling, white hair streaming in the rain. Roland swivels around, to see -- A gathering crowd of sodden, desperate scholars: Beatrice Cropper, Hildebrand, Fergus, gloomy; ever Blackadder and Leonora.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAIN POURS down. In the bar, around a fireplace, a muddy crew of scholars, in pajamas and dressing gowns, drink ho toddies; Blackadder and Leonora hold hands, in love. Beatrice passes around the letters.

dialogues.speaker: BLACKADDER
dialogues.text: How strange for Maud to be descended from both Ash and Christabel...

dialogues.speaker: FERGUS
dialogues.text: Yes. Your lives' work, all in vain...

dialogues.speaker: CROPPER
dialogues.text: No, no. I sensed it all along. The old Cropper instinct. I knew it was something vast...

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: I can imagine Ellen. She didn't even read it. Just put it away --

dialogues.speaker: BLACKADDER
dialogues.text: For Maud. As it turns out. She preserved it for Maud.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: Poor Ash. He never knew... never knew.. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Looking to Leonora, for once speechless, gazing at a damp letter.

dialogues.speaker: LEONORA
dialogues.text: Wow. PULL BACK from the discussion -- TO upstairs -- where --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THROUGH the windows of the 18th Century inn -- In a white room, with a white four-poster, with white-vei curtains. Maud and Roland by a white bed.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I'm afraid of it, too. Just like you.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: What cowards we are, after all. (beat) Kiss me.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: That's what I was afraid of. Behind the white veils, Maud finally kisses Roland, softl at first, then with all her repressed passion, as they li down upon the bed --

dialogues.speaker: DOWN BY BED
dialogues.text: And beside it -- the WATCH. With its plait of golden hair where we HOLD for a moment. Until, weakly, fitfully, the sweeping second-hand gasps out a few inexplicable TICKS - enough to let us know -- It is alive.

dialogues.speaker: ASH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: There are things that happen and leave no discernible trace, are not spoken of or written of, as though such things have never been. Two people met, on a hot May day, and never mentioned the meeting...

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: The same WATCH, TICKING... In the hands of a man, walking down a country lane on a h May day of bright sunlight and BUZZING INSECTS. Nearby, a meadow full of flowers, like a Monet: blue cornflowers, scarlet poppies, a carpet of yellow daisies sway in the breeze. Up a lane, walks a bearded man in a black, wide-brimmed h From cool shadows, he stares wistfully out in the distanc at -- the gothic towers of Seal Court. The old man is hot wipes his brow. As he catches his breath, a nearby CREAKING sound, to and fro, distracts him. Yet so intense is his stare, he hardl notices a young GIRL (8), swinging on a gate.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Hello! Are you lost? The Girl, in blue dress and white pinafore, hums to herse making a daisy chain. The man looks down at her: he is Ash.

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: Am I -- ? Oh, hello. Yes... I was looking up at yonder house. Do you know it?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: That house? Of course I do. That's my house.

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: (beat) Is it really? Suddenly curious, Ash cocks his head towards her, lowers himself on one knee. A gentle matter-of-fact tenderness.

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: Well, you are a very fortunate girl. (holding out his hand) My name is Randolph Ash. How do you do? May I know yours?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL, (MAY)
dialogues.text: My name is May Bailey. I have another name also, but I do not like it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: I think I know your mother. You have a true look of your mother.

dialogues.speaker: MAY
dialogues.text: No one else says that. I think I look like my father.

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: I think you have a look of your father, too. Ash puts his arms around her waist, lifts her down to his side. Mays sits, pulling grass, surrounded by a cloud of butterflies. Ash hunts scissors. hair.

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: You seem very happy.

dialogues.speaker: MAY
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. I am, I am. (beat) Can you make daisy chains?

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: I will make you a crown for a May Queen. But you must give me something in exchange.

dialogues.speaker: MAY
dialogues.text: I haven't got anything to give.

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: Oh, just a lock of hair. To remember you by.

dialogues.speaker: MAY
dialogues.text: Like a fairy story.

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: Just so. in his satchel, takes out a tiny pair of pocket And very gently cuts a long lock from her golden

dialogues.speaker: MAY
dialogues.text: Here. I'll plait it for you, to keep it tidy. May's fingers set to work, Ash gathers up twigs, ferns, flowers. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: I'll make you a crown, like a fairy's child. Or like Proserpine. Do you know any poetry?

dialogues.speaker: MAY
dialogues.text: I have an Aunt Christabel who is always telling me poems. But I don't like poetry.

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: I am sorry you don't like poetry, as I am a poet.

dialogues.speaker: MAY
dialogues.text: Oh, I like you. You make lovely things and don't fuss.

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: If I wrote down a message, would you be kind enough to deliver it to your aunt?

dialogues.speaker: MAY
dialogues.text: A message? What will it say?

dialogues.speaker: ASH
dialogues.text: Simply that you met a poet, who was looking for his fairy goddess, and who met you instead, and who sends her his compliments, and will not disturb her, and is on his way to fresh woods and pastures anew. Ash locks into May's eyes. A moment he will remember with absolute clarity, but which will fade in her memory over years. Tiny beetles crawl about their feet. They go back to working beneath the sun. A man and a girl content to share one moment of their lives. As a breeze floats through, ruffling the leaves around them --

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: Ash stands by the gate, watching May run through the mead note in hand, daisy crown upon her head. Ash winds her blonde hair-plait around the chain of his watch. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: May climbs up a hill towards Seal Court, where her brothe ambush her. They rough and tumble, falling down the grass slope. Her crown falls beneath one brother, is crushed. Among her things, May picks up her half-embroidered cushi (the one Maud finds a hundred years on) with verses only begun. Ash turns away as --

dialogues.speaker: HIS NOTE
dialogues.text: without May even registering -- Flies from her hand, up into the air. Carried by the wind like a leaf, it floats through the fields. Over the grass connected by diamond-threads of light -- Over the yellow and purple flowers, up into the branches a tree. When a wind blows, RUSTLING LEAVES, seeming to pl music upon them. HOLD ON the tree. SLOW PAN THROUGH TO -- END OF FLASHBACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That same tree. <A hundred years later. Now full circle, growing magically in an elegant square in central London. As the WIND RUSHES through the branches, in an ancient harmony -- About to pluck from its branches to tap upon a library window -- Leaves, floating like birds. FADE TO BLACK.
